results.description:
For the week of Together 2016 festival we invite you to visit the Mmmmaven Recharge Lounge. It will open Monday, May 16th through the 22nd as your place to meet festival-goers and the Together team, listen to local DJs, power up, relax, and hydrate before the evening's festivities. Don't miss hands-on interactive workshops with leading music technology brands, like Novation, Ableton, and Denon more. Check out full schedule here.


A live demonstration of the Your Heaven® Close-Up® Mic System, an affordable product that allows you to easily integrate acoustic instruments like guitars, strings and drums into your music. With a unique combination of both the isolation needed for live performance and the fidelity you’d normally only get in a studio, you can amplify, record or sample beautiful acoustic instruments live, right on stage as you perform - with no feedback or crosstalk problems. We’ll show you how to use it with acoustic guitar, electric guitar and drums. We will also demonstrate how the Your Heaven® Close-Up® can be incorporated into both the production and live performance setup of an electronic musician, to be processed and used as a trigger source for midi instruments. 

Arvid Tomayko-Peters is a performing experimental musician, multimedia artist and audio engineer who hails from the foggy tip of Cape Cod. He holds a BA in both Computer Music and Multimedia and Geological Sciences from Brown University where he studied with teachers such as Alvin Lucier. At Your Heaven®, he codes software and firmware, develops algorithms, records instruments for acoustic research, tests hardware and designs the exterior of the products. Arvid's goal at Your Heaven® is to help start the instrument pickup revolution that will make live music on acoustic instruments sound better. His personal work focuses on building electronic performance systems for realtime musical improvisation.

Steve Schwartz is a musician and audio engineer. He studied composition at Juilliard, and completed his music degree at Brown University, where he also studied audio engineering and studio technique. After graduating, he taught music theory and recording at Brown's Music Dept. He still manages recordings for the department, sings with the Brown University Chorus, runs Brown's Klezmer band, and plays jazz and experimental music whenever he gets a chance. The technology behind the Your Heaven® systems was born in his basement while still a student, when he started building devices to help him with recording his drums for recording class assignments.

Justin Satriano is a musician who holds a master’s degree in Computer Science from Brown University. Leader and composer for jazz-rock quartet The Stride, he has worked as a software developer at MOTU, and has recently been beta testing the Your Heaven® Guitar Amplifier system. He will be demonstrating this product at the presentation on Wednesday, May 18 and at the Synthesizer Petting Zoo on May 22 (both at MMMMaven). 

Mitchell Owens is a guitar player, sound designer, and electronic composer/producer from Durham, NC. He attended Berklee College of Music right here in Boston and has over 5 years of experience with Ableton Live producing and performing music under the moniker Subalias, as well as doing sound design and soundtrack composition for independent films and animations. Mitchell’s music blends the organic and synthetic for a balanced fusion inspired by sample based Hip­Hop, Downtempo, House, Funk and R&B. He believes in freedom of creation and expression and likes to cater to students’ specific needs in order to teach them the proper skills and techniques needed to achieve their musical goals.

</a>

Follow Together on <a href="https://twitter.com/together">Twitter, Instagram, & Facebook!

<a href="http://togetherboston.com/2016-schedule/"></a>
results.name: INNOVATIVE ACOUSTIC INSTRUMENT SOUND CAPTURE W/ YOUR HEAVEN®

results.description:
Wednesday night is our (almost) weekly get-together for open gaming at the Panera Bread location in Porter Square. All are welcome to join us, regardless of experience level!


If you have a game you are particularly interested in playing, you are welcome and encouraged to bring it. But this is not required; many people typically bring a selection of their favorites and we're always happy to teach. The only things you need to bring are an open mind and a good attitude. If you're particularly hot to try something out, you are encouraged to leave a comment and see if you can drum up some interest beforehand. Please bear in mind that table space is limited, so an especially huge or epic game may not be appropriate for the venue (but see our Sunday night event at Pandemonium in Central Square for an alternative venue).


The event officially opens at 7 PM, but some people like to show up early; those who show up early should feel free to get started on a shorter warm-up game if time allows.


We look forward to seeing you at the gaming table!


WHERE WE SIT: Unless the restaurant is super-crowded, we gather in the basement dining area; just look for the games and say hi. We're friendly, honest!


GETTING THERE:


The Panera is located within easy walking distance of the Red Line T and several bus lines, and public transit is probably the easiest way of getting there. If you drive, mall parking is (theoretically) limited to 2 hours except where posted. I've never heard of anyone getting towed for overstaying this limit. For the extra-cautious, there are metered spots on Mass Ave; check the meter to be sure but most Cambridge meters don't need to be fed after 6 PM or 7 PM. There is also a Hubway bike-share station less than five minute's walk from the mall.


SOME NOTES:


As a group, we don't usually make a huge deal about attendance policy, however: attendance at these events is limited, and our Panera events are usually not huge; one side effect of this is that RSVPing and then not showing up can have a disruptive effect on our events, and for particularly popular events, "no shows" take up a spot from someone who wanted to be there. Bottom line: If you RSVP for a Panera event, please make a good-faith effort to show up or at least let us know if you can't make it.


As far as possible, please also let us know if you're going to be more than a few minutes late. As a rule of thumb, if we haven't heard from you and you arrive after 7:15 or so, you're likely to be limited to a spot at whatever game has room for an extra player. Much later than that, and we'll almost certainly be underway without you! You're welcome to show up and socialize and of course we'll try to accomodate you if we can, but we can't guarantee you a game. Because we as a group tend to play longer and more involved games, most groups at our events tend to play one and only one game per night.


Panera has been quite gracious about hosting our group with minimal fuss. To ensure that this happy state of affairs continues, please give them some business if you're hungry or thirsty and (especially) respect the hardworking people who work there, and their desire to go home after a long shift -- be ready to leave when the restaurant closes at ten.
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

Be curious.

Come with an open mind, and leave with a full heart.

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability, so you actually get your work done and turn your dreams into reality

• Ideas and inspiration to help you make something new or improve what you already have

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall. No pressure at all. Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it (although we will say hello to you and give you the opportunity to introduce yourself, if you'd like).

Meeting Agenda:

7:00pm Join the meeting here:

https://hangouts.google.com/hangouts/_/daviddrayton.com/weeklyautomatedincomemastermindmeeting

Each week, we do two things at our remote meetings, which we hold through Google Hangouts:

1) Part 1: Status check-ups (20-30 minutes): New members introduce themselves, sharing a bit about their goals and what they hope to get out of the group.  Existing members updates the group on the past week's biggest wins, and provide any other updates that stood out to them that week.

Each member may ask a short question or solicit help from the group as a whole before moving onto the next person, though any topics that deserve more than a minute or two of discussion will be moved to the next part of the meeting.

2) Part 2: Focus Groups (60 minutes+): The group splits out into two focus groups: one focused on selling physical products through platforms, and the other focused on producing and marketing online content.  Examples of the former may include people selling products on Amazon, Etsy, Ebay, through their e-commerce stores, etc.  Examples of the latter would include podcasters, bloggers, affiliate marketers, etc.

This second portion of the meeting may last for as long as the members within that focus group would like to extend the conversation, and members may hop on and off of either conversation at any time.

If you are in the physical product group, you can stay put in your current Google Hangout.  If you're in the online content marketing group, please join this hangout once Part 2 of the meeting begins:

https://hangouts.google.com/hangouts/_/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea



Anyone can join. It doesn't matter where you are, how older you are, or even what stage of your business you're in. Our regular members include everyone from total beginners who are just getting their feet wet all the way up to serial entrepreneurs who are already making six-figures or more in their spare time doing this stuff.
results.how_to_find_us: Google Hangouts.  JOIN BY GOING TO  THIS LINK:  http://bit.ly/1XagvaN .  If it's your first time, I suggest giving it a test run before the actual meeting to work out any technical kinks.

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11

FREE REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
http://devlab-boston-2016.eventbrite.com/?aff=muade1

Join the AT&T Developer Program on May 18th for a free 3-hour, hands-on coding workshop taught by AT&T’s lead architect for WebRTC.

WebRTC (Web Real-Time Communication) is an API definition drafted by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) that supports browser-to-browser applications for voice calling, video chat, and P2P file sharing without the need of either internal or external plugins.

Walk through various coding examples and then AT&T subject matter experts will provide help as you go through the lab exercises yourself. The workshop focuses on a carrier-agnostic version of the AT&T API and will work with any web app running in Chrome.

Offered twice on May 18th: 12pm or 5pm.
This event is free and complimentary lunch or dinner will be provided.

Bring your Windows or Mac laptop and join us for an afternoon or evening of learning, coding, socializing, and eating!

Seating is very limited so sign up soon!

Register here: http://devlab-boston-2016.eventbrite.com/?aff=muade1

results.description:
Welcome new members!  Please note, RSVPs are required to attend this 35-person, multi-site game night.  The open RSVP spots on Meetup are for new members.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have about 35 attendees each week, including regulars and new members.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.  If you are having a hard time getting a spot, please send a message to the organizer and we will try to work something out!

2. We ask new members for a one-time donation of $5 towards our site fees.  After that, game night is completely free!

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for when the room is less full -- typically we thin out slightly by 10:00.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  (We do play some light games, but if that's the main thing you want to play, please try our Light Game Night instead!)  Our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right.  We ask new members for a one-time donation of $5.00 that goes towards site fees.

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza. We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot). When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.

results.description:
Hi All,


We are going to try something new for this Meetup. Three Entrepreneurs who have recently founded their own Companies have generously offered to discuss their unique paths and provide insight into the many challenges that they faced along the way. Join us at Gamer Duel Headquarters (right by South Station) to ask the questions and advice that you can only get from someone who's been in the thick of it. 

Our Presenters will be: 

Nathan Dionne - CEO of Gamerduel and Former CTO of Barstool Sports

Sam Marley - CEO of Blurr, SXSW Pitch finalist

Manny Lubin - Co-CEO of Reppr which is reimagining the brand ambassador model

If you have any topics / questions that you'd like them to cover, please email them to me in advance ([masked]). Some topics / questions that I've received so far from hckr/hstlrs:

• How did they choose (or how they met) people they co-founded startups with (if they have cofounders)? How did you convince each other to work for free?


• If you have co-founder(s), how did you decide on the equity breakdowns amongst co-founder(s)?

• How did they know the concept that they chose was 'the one' ?


• How did you objectively evaluate the Market Opportunity?


• How did you objectively evaluate the competitive landscape?


• How did they validate / prove their concept?


• How much iteration and what was the iteration framework before they arrived on the market ready product?


• How do you balance feedback from people about the product - ie. "it'll never work", "it's great!", "someone's sort of already doing that"? All from people who are supposed to be experts. 


• Did they balance starting the venture with working a day job? If so, what were some of the challenges there? Any tips?


• Walk us through some of the legal / financial 'chores' involved in starting the venture (forming an llc etc.). Any tips?

• In your recruiting efforts, what was effective and what wasn't?


• Have you ever successfully pitched an investor on a concept without a working prototype?


• Walk us through the process of raising capital. Any advice?

Thanks and see you there!

George
results.name: 3 Successful Entrepreneurs Discuss Their Path to Founding Local Boston Startups

results.description:
Great Huffington Post article on judging: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mara-shapshay/are-you-a-supreme-judge-i_b_9532206.html.  


Good judgment, bad judgment.  It is often suggested in our times, that we should not judge others because we have not walked in their shoes.  That does not stop most of us.  It seems, despite our intentions not to be judgmental, that is precisely how we behave, believing that our conclusions about how the world works, and which beliefs and actions, are correct.  So are we wrong?  Are we hypocritical?  Is it better to reserve judgment - do we feel capable to judge the Marathon Bomber?  Are there sources of judgment other than first hand personal experience?  Maybe when we judge, even correctly, our judgments are limited by the smallness of our perspective, we're too close to the ground to see the bigger picture, at other times perhaps its limited by the distance by which we judge the subject, we're too high in the clouds to see the matter in its gritty detail.  

I hope you can make it!

results.name: Judging others

The Boston Dyke March is an amazing alt-Pride event that gives space and voice to those often overshadowed both in society and in the queer community. We are intersectional and inclusive -the Dyke March is for EVERYONE, regardless of gender identity, orientation, age, religion, race, background, or ability. Want be part of something big in your community while meeting new people and having fun? We'd love to have you!

In addition to the March itself in June, we plan events and activities throughout the year, have fun Committee social outings, advocate for social change, and generally be awesome. We're looking to shake things up and grow, and we want you to be part of that. We are a consensus based, grassroots, totally volunteer-run group, so every voice matters. We hope to see you there!

results.description:
Software prodigy Josie Ashkenazi has invented an application that records everything its users do. When an Egyptian library invites her to visit as a consultant, her jealous sister Judith persuades her to go. But in Egypt’s postrevolutionary chaos, Josie is abducted―leaving Judith free to take over Josie’s life at home, including her husband and daughter, while Josie’s talent for preserving memories becomes a surprising test of her empathy and her only means of escape.
A century earlier, another traveler arrives in Egypt: Solomon Schechter, a Cambridge professor hunting for a medieval archive hidden in a Cairo synagogue. Both he and Josie are haunted by the work of the medieval philosopher Moses Maimonides, a doctor and rationalist who sought to reconcile faith and science, destiny and free will. But what Schechter finds, as he tracks down the remnants of a thousand-year-old community’s once-vibrant life, will reveal the power and perils of what Josie’s ingenious work brings into being: a world where nothing is ever forgotten.

An engrossing adventure that intertwines stories from Genesis, medieval philosophy, and the digital frontier, A Guide for the Perplexed is a novel of profound inner meaning and astonishing imagination.
results.how_to_find_us: Reservation for 12 under Jessie
results.name: A Guide for the Perplexed by Dara Horn

results.description:
Our lighter games meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, a few buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 11:00.  There are two excellent cafes right there, Clover and Bailey & Sage.  Their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, The Resistance: Avalon, Bang! The Dice Game, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Saboteur, 6 Nimmt!, Hanabi, No Thanks!, Incan Gold, Forbidden Island

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Not as Light Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Face the street and walk one building to your right.  The entrance is right in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Cross the street, turn left and walk past one building.  The entrance is right in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) Walk back to Main Street.  Cross the street, turn left and walk past one building.  The entrance is right in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) Walk back to Main Street.  Cross the street, turn left and walk past one building.  The entrance is right in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.

If you’ve ever shopped for a 3-D printer you know there's a wide range of options depending on what you're planning to print  and finding the right printer requires some research plus an opportunity to see some 3-D printer in action.  This meetup on May 18th at the Roxbury Innovation Center from 7:00 PM – 9:00 PM will provide you with everything you need to know about 3-D printers.


The first part of the meeting from 7:00 PM - 8:00 PM will be an opportunity to see NVbots (http://nvbots.com/) and FormLab printers (http://formlabs.com/ ) in action as well as meet other Fab Labbers and Makers and enjoy some wine and light bites. 

From 8:00 to 9:00 PM Christopher Haid will provide an overview of the major 3-D printer technologies on the market including their relative strengths, the differences between filament and resin based products, and other useful info. 

This meeting in sponsored in part by FABLabhub (http://fablabhub.org/)

$10.00 fee will cover the cost of wine and appetizers.

Make your reservation now!

results.description:
We've learned a lot of technical skills at Maptime; this month let's step back and talk about cartographic design! Friendly, practical guides to principles and best practices of map design are a little harder to come by than technical tutorials. Drawing on recent workshops, Mike and Andy will briefly cover some of the concepts, guidelines, and occasional rules of cartography that lead to good maps—as well as practical resources for achieving good map design. Then as a group we can look at example maps and talk about some of those principles in action.

Have a favorite map? Bring it along we can discuss what makes its design work well. Looking for design advice on a map you're working on? Bring that too!

Can you or your organization sponsor this event? Please get in touch with the organizers if so! Besides everyone's gratitude, event sponsors will have a few minutes to speak to the group about their company, their work, or anything at all.

--------


Maptime is, rather literally, time for mapmaking. Our mission is to open the doors of cartographic possibility to anyone interested by creating a time and space for collaborative learning, exploration, and map creation using mapping tools and technologies.


This open learning environment for all levels and degrees of knowledge offers intentional support for the beginner. Maptime is simultaneously flexible and structured, creating space for workshops, ongoing projects with a shared goal, and independent/collaborative work time.


Inspiration for Maptime comes from both hack nights and knitting circles. Both are models of spaces for people to create and learn together. Our goal is to provide this space with an open heart and without pretension. You can bring your own projects to work on, or just hang out and socialize or ask questions. Some people are experts, and some people are just getting started, but all of us are learning, so why not do it together?


Maptime is hands-on, so don't forget to bring your laptop!
results.how_to_find_us: Check in at security with your ID and let them know you're here for Maptime, then head to the 4th floor.
results.name: Map Design: Principles and Best Practices of Cartography

results.description:
Joel Fishbein will be leading this sound awareness meditation. 

We are adding a new location: Ten Thousand Villages in Downtown Boston.  It's very exciting!  Please be aware that we now have two different Ten Thousand Villages stores that host our events.  Make sure that you are going to the correct store.  

Make sure to arrive early to settle in, around 7pm is a good time because we do lock the door right at 7:15. Our official event start time is now 7:15pm. 

Our schedule: 

7pm - It's great to arrive early to ask questions and find a good seat. We have chitchat time starting around 7:00. Come hang out with us, ask the teacher questions, and feel free to peruse the store. 

7:15pm - Class starts.
Please note: We lock the door at 7:15pm so make sure to arrive early. Please do not disturb the class by trying to enter or knocking. 

8:30pm - Class ends. 

What happens during class: 
   The 75 minutes that we spend together will include: 
           1) discussion about meditation and mindfulness 
           2) instructions on how to meditate 
           3) an experience of a sound awareness meditation 
The length of the meditation itself will probably be about 15 to 25 minutes long. No previous experience is required; the meditation will be easy for beginners to understand. 


More info: 

Our website has more information about the history of our Community Meditation Nights. http://www.mindfulboston.com/classes/#/community-meditation-nights/

What to bring:
It's fine to just show up as you are.
Yet, please be aware that (as you can see in the pictures) most of us do sit on the floor. Some folks choose to bring their own pillow for sitting on the floor, but there are no requirements to bring anything. 

If you require a chair for health reasons, make sure to RSVP and write "please reserve a chair for me" in the comments section below. We have about seven chairs, and typically 20 to 30 people participate.
results.name: Boston location:  Community Meditation Night- Sound Awareness

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 47 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.description:
The Public Open Night at the Observatory is a chance for people to come observe the night sky through telescopes and binoculars and see things they otherwise might not get to see, and learn some astronomy as well. The Open Nights are held most Wednesday evenings throughout the year, weather permitting.

The program starts promptly at 7:30pm during the fall and winter months,and 8:30pm during the spring and summer months.

Please arrive early as there is no admittance once the program begins.

We start admitting ticketed guests 10 minutes before the program begins.

Right before the program starts and after all the ticketed guests that are present are admitted, we will admit any non-ticketed guests until we reach capacity.

Weather
The weather is always a factor when observing. Unfortunately we can’t control the weather and we can’t observe when there are clouds, haze, or rain; so when the weather is bad, the Open Night will be canceled. Predicting the weather in New England isn’t easy, so we won’t know if the Open Night will be held or not until the day of the program. This lets us make the decision as late as possible while still giving those who live farther away time to get here. Remember, it gets very cold in Boston in the winter and the telescopes are outside, so dress warmly.

To find out if the Open Night will be held, call our information number at[masked], or check our Twitter feed (twitter.com/buobservatory): no earlier than two hours before the scheduled starting time.

Location
The Public Open Night is held at the Coit Observatory at Boston University. We are located at 725 Commonwealth Avenue in Boston, MA, above the Astronomy Department. The stairwell up to the Observatory is on the fifth floor just to the left of room 520.

Unfortunately, there is no disabled access to the Observatory.

Information
For information about Open Night, please call[masked], or check our Twitter feed (twitter.com/buobservatory):

Source(s):
New member, Manny reminded me about...
http://www.bostonastronomy.net/Public%20Viewing.html
http://www.bu.edu/astronomy/events/public-open-night-at-the-observatory/

Watch for tickets here:
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/boston-university-open-night-tickets-20559405736
results.name: Boston University - Public Open Night at the Coit Observatory

results.description:
This week, we'll be playing Zendo, the beautifully simple game of inductive logic. One player, the master, sets a rule for structures of pieces. For example, they might decide all of the pieces must be different sizes. The other players then have to figure out the rule by building structures and asking if they meet the rule. It's the heart of science captured in a game. You can read more about it here:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zendo_(game)

Our schedule is as follows:

• 7:30 Arrival and introductions

• 8pm Game begins

• 11pm End

Attendees are welcome to bring snacks, drinks, or game recommendations.
results.name: Wednesday Game Night: Zendo

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

results.description:
Tune in at http://www.philosophicperspectives.com

The Social Philosophizers Club periodically holds somewhat spontaneous or spur of the moment meetings called Impromptu Philosophizers. Well, in an impromptu spirit, I decided to ask the small group on Monday (5/16/2016) if they would like to record the discussion for the the radio show two days hence. We all agreed!


I launched a short talk between connections of intellectual spontaneity with a serious and fun loving aspect of philosophy and philosophizing.  The the talk drifted to the current presidential election campaign, and then some broader observations about the influence that American presidents have or do not have, critiques of politics, and the state of the union. It was a lot of fun. I hope that you can listen to the broadcast, but as always, a  podcast of the show will be available for free download within 24 hours after the show's conclusion.

My thanks to Jos Visser, Barry Harris, Josh M-K and Larry Spencer to participating! It was a lot of fun. It was also an experiment, and I think at-event broadcasts will become an important aspect of the show moving forward. And yes, the technology employed will be improved; although I was surprised how well it actually turned out!


*******************

Your RSVP indicates that you plan on listening to the show. After listening to the broadcast or the subsequently posted podcast you will  be able to post comments on this page. (No, Cyberville MA is not a real place! But I look forward to "seeing" you on the radio, May 16th 2016, 10pm Eastern/7pm Pacific.)

Philosophic Perspectives with Arthur D. Schwartz. Visit the show page at: http://www.philosophicperspectives.com
results.name: Impromptu Philosophizer Broadcast!

results.description:
ABM is a method that marketers use to analyze market growth potential, listen for customer signals, and find new entry points for sales.

Current customers are your best path to sales growth, so how can marketing partner with sales to find and close new opportunities at existing accounts? Account Based Marketing (ABM) is a method that marketers use to analyze market growth potential, listen for customer signals, and find new entry points for sales. Join Mark Goloboy, a digital marketing strategist who developed ABM programs at Monster, AspenTech, and EMC. Mark will present and lead this month's breakfast discussion on how your company can use ABM to target top customers, align sales and marketing efforts and grow these most valuable accounts.


(And then, in a special home and away event with Boston's Agile Marketing Meetup, on the same day Mark will be presenting on how to use agile management to implement ABM.)

Mark will be sharing his experiences around:
- Developing an ABM methodology that fits your Go-To-Market approach,
- Evaluating Customer Engagement Tools and Techniques, and
- Measuring ABM Success As usual with a SAMI breakfast we’ll have a lively exchange of experiences and thought provoking questions.

Are you a sales or marketing leader looking to sharpen your skills, learn from experts, and network with peers? Are you on your way up to the leadership level and want to practice discussing executive level topics with *actual* executives? SAMI breakfasts are the place for you! And registration includes a full breakfast at the Newton Marriott Riverbend restaurant. Join us on the 19th!
results.name: Growing Revenue from Existing Customers with Account Based Marketing

results.description:
Join MassBio for our first Forum jointly hosted with the Medical Development Group (MDG), a premier organization for leading Medical Device and Medical Technology professionals.

This event is Free and open to the public.

(Registration recommended due to limited space).

TO REGISTER: https://www.massbio.org/events/drug-meets-device-the-power-of-combination-products-1245

Combination products are the best of both worlds; blending drugs and devices in ways that offer patients benefits that neither could offer alone. These include products that deliver drugs in a unique way, such as artificial pancreas systems, and products that use drugs to enhance the function of a device, such as drug eluting stents. Combination product technology has already measurably improved patient outcomes. New technologies to improve the integration of drugs with devices are the focus of both industry R&D and academic research.

Though the potential is great, these technologies also pose unique scientific and regulatory challenges that may not be obvious at the outset. As with all new technologies, an effective business strategy is essential for commercialization.

Our panel of industry experts will explore key issues including:
•Basic science of device-associated drug delivery
•Regulatory pathways for combination products
•Investment strategy
•Intellectual property

Speakers:
•Richard Anders, JD, Founder, Executive Director, Mass Medical Angels
•Andrew Bellinger, MD, PhD, Chief Scientific Officer, Lyndra Co.
•Jonathan C. Bretz, OT/L, MBA, RAC President & Founder, RSQM Associates, LLC
•John Keating, DVM, DACVP, Director of Pathology, CBSET Inc, Lexington, MA

Moderator:
•Ibraheem (Ib) T. Badejo, PhD, Senior Director, New Ventures (Medical Devices), Johnson & Johnson Innovation Center

                              Live-stream this Forum
results.name: Drug Meets Device: The Power of Combination Products

results.description:
Apache Apex is a native Hadoop data-in-motion platform that is used for ingestion, transformations, fast real-time analytics, ETL, disastor recovery, etc. 

Processing big data often requires running the same computations parallelly in multiple processes or threads, called partitions, with each partition handling a subset of the data. This becomes all the more necessary when processing live data streams where maintaining SLA is paramount. Furthermore, multiple different computations make up an application and each of them may have different partitioning needs. Partitioning also needs to adapt to changing data rates, input sources and other application requirements like SLA.

In this talk we will introduce how Apex, a distributed data-in-motion platform on Hadoop, handles partitioning. We will look at different partitioning schemes provided by Apex some of which are unique in this space. We will also look at how Apex does dynamic partitioning, a feature unique to and pioneered by Apex to handle varying data needs with examples. We will also talk about the different utilities and libraries that Apex provides for users to be able to affect their own custom partitioning.

Presenters: 

- Pramod Immaneni Apache Apex PMC member, and architect at DataTorrent Inc, where he works on Apex and big data applications. Prior to DataTorrent he was a co-founder and CTO of Leaf Networks LLC, where he built products in core networking space and was granted patents in peer-to-peer VPNs. Prior to that he was a technical co-founder of a mobile startup where he architected a dynamic content rendering engine for mobile devices.

- Thomas Weise Apache Apex PMC member, and architect and co-founder at DataTorrent Inc. A Hadoop veteran.

Please register at - https://www.brighttalk.com/webcast/13685/194119

For deeper engagement with Apache Apex - follow ApacheApex, presentations, recordings, download, Apache Apex releases, docs

<a href="http://apex.apache.org/docs.html"></a>

This webcast covers content from a previous meetup in San Jose, we are webcasting it to enable other Big Data Ingesters to participate. If you are interested in helping organize (hosting, presenting, community leadership) Apache Apex community, please email [masked]
results.name: Smart Partitioning in Apache Apex - Next Gen Hadoop Big Data-In-Motion Platform

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Thursday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
***********************

To join the May Tourney please just go through our Join Page:  http://TennisNorthEast.com/join
***********************


How does the TennisNorthEast Tournament Work?

Every Match Counts *NEW* for 2015

Tennis Tournament Basic Concept

 Our tournaments are a single elimination format with a consolation bracket. Meaning you are guaranteed at least 2 matches. This tournament format will not be played at a single location over a weekend instead players are given 7 to 10 days to play each round's match.

 Our tournaments will be mixed gender unless we have particularly strong female enrollment in a city. The tournaments will be singles based until we receive enough response to open it up for doubles. Players will be grouped in brackets with players no greater than .5 of their current TLN League Rating. Meaning Skilled - 3.0 players will be matched with other 3.0 players and at most with Competitive - 3.5 level players. Competitive - 3.5 level players could be grouped with Advanced - 4.0 players but will not have Elite 4.5 level players in their bracket.

Our Guarantee

 We need at least 6 players to make a tournament bracket. If we can NOT reach this criteria then we will refund your entry fee and give you the next tournament for no cost. Our hope is to run multiple skill level brackets for each tournament. We are NOT going to show early enrollment for the tournaments. Also the 7-day money back guarantee expires as soon as the tournament starts. Tournaments will not allow for late enrollment.

Leveling

 All tournament players will need to have played 4 league/season or tennis ladder legacy matches before they can enter into a tournament. Players will be entered into the tournament that associates with their TLN's Player Rating. If a player wants to participate in a second draw at a rating higher than their Player Rating they will be allowed too.

Your Schedule and Availability

 These tournaments will be kicked off on Thursday's giving the first round opponents two weekends to play the first match and then each following round will have a full week to play the match. Players need to be local for at least the first 3 weeks after kickoff. Players with 1-week work trips or week long vacations during the first 3 weeks shouldn't participate in the tournament.

Seedings

  The TennisNorthEast staff will seed 25% of the participants based veteran status (Most number of matches played in their career) with the program. If we have 8 players enrolled we'll seed the top 2 players, 16 players the top 4 players. The rest of the players will be randomly entered into the draw.

Consolation Bracket

 We will run a consolation bracket for the players who lost their first match. Seedings for the consolation bracket will be randomly selected by the TennisNorthEast staff. The winner of the consolation bracket will receive a $25 Tennis Warehouse Gift Card.

Where to Play?

  Because the seeding of the tournament is mainly randomize the higher seed will NOT have home court preference. The league strongly suggests you meet half-way to cut the commute in half for both players. We provide an extensive list of tennis courts that have user submitted ratings. If two players need guidance they can certainly email our staff for suggestions.

Playing Format

  The preferred playing format for tournaments should be 2 sets with a 3rd set tie-breaker or 2 out of 3 sets. If the two players can't agree the default format will be the 2 sets with a 3rd set tie-breaker. In NYC we will accept 10 game pro set results mainly due to court availability.

Target Audience

  This will be our most competitive format. The target audience is for the player who are good sports and love to play competitive matches.

Prize Pool

 The prize pool will be based upon enrollment in each bracket. A tournament can have multiple brackets. The tournament prize structure is based around our partner Tennis Warehouse (TW).

6 to 10 players: $50 TW Gift Card for the winner*, $25 TW GC for Finalist, $25 TW GC for Consolation bracket winner
11 to 16: $100 TW GC for the winner* + Trophy, $50 TW GC for Finalist, $25 TW GC for Consolation winner
17 to 24: $150 TW GC for the winner* + Trophy, $50 TW GC for Finalist, $25 TW GC for 3rd & 4th place, $50 TW GC for Consolation winner
25+: $200 TW GC for the winner* + Trophy, $100 TW GC for Finalist, $25 TW GC for 3rd and 4th place, $50 TW GC for Consolation winner

 All tournament champions will be receive an entry into the End of the Year National Tourneys at the champions discounted rate.

Cost to Participate

Tourney's have a new cost structure for 2016. First ten players will pay only $19.95. Next ten players will pay $22.95 and any following players will pay $24.95.

Join Today!!

So Join Today and we'd be happy to get you enrolled into the next tournament.

results.description:
Will Robots Rule the World?

 A Panel Discussion about Artificial Intelligence

Thursday, May 19, 2016; 5:30 p.m. – 8:30 p.m.

Location: Carbonite, 2 Avenue de Lafayette, Boston, MA

$15, members and students; $25, non-members

When we hear the term “Artificial Intelligence” (AI), we may think of self-driving cars, drones that will deliver our holiday packages, and computers defeating humans at board games. Some pundits are talking about a massive shift in our society with AI replacing huge quantities of humans in the workforce within the next 10 years. Perhaps some people envision SkyNet from the Terminator movies running amuck.

Companies are already using AI in numerous ways, including Google and Apple, which are leveraging AI to improve search and smartphones’ intelligent assistant, respectively. It’s employed behind the scenes to address a range of needs, such as fraud detection, leveraging patient data to improve healthcare, and tracing human traffickers.

So, what’s next for AI? Clearly we’ll all be affected by its benefits and its drawbacks, as well as its ever-growing technological applications. Join WITI Boston for a panel discussion with cognitive-computing and AI experts, and hear what the future holds.

Beverages and light appetizers will be served. Carbonite is located near the Chinatown and Downtown Crossing T stops and is next door to a parking garage.


For more information and to register: http://goo.gl/pRpkfw
results.name: WITI Boston: Will Robots Rule the World?

This workshop includes preparation demonstrations of different recipes involving fermented foods. Participants will be able to sample a variety of fermented products.

Let's go to the Third Thursday, Jazz in Boston, special event at the Isabella Stewart Museum.  (http://www.gardnermuseum.org/calendar/events/6971)

Shift your perspective this spring. Soak up the shadowy ambiance of the palace at night, then brighten up with hands-on art making in the studio.   Gather in the evening at the Gardner, soak up the atmosphere of the historic courtyard garden, and explore the light-filled spaces of the new wing. 

Free music and a cash wine bar each night, plus artist and spotlight talks in the galleries. Join in clever gallery games, sketching, and a chance to get a little messy in our new art studio too. Each night is a bit different from the next and sure to spark conversation and delight.

 Joana

results.description:
This meeting is sponsored by Trip Advisor.

Meeting will be at their North End offices.

Java and Web Services:  Using Swagger to Define and Implement APIs

Swagger can provide beautiful documentation for your web service, but also defines a powerful interface. With the right tooling, that interface can be used to auto generate client SDKs and even servers.  In this talk, we’ll use open-source and SAAS tools to generate both client and server implementations so you can worry about your business logic instead of web service plumbing.

Tony Tam

Vice President of Products, Swagger


Tony Tam has been the driving force behind Swagger, the leading API description format used by developers in almost every modern programming language and deployment environment to design and deliver APIs that fuel IoT, microservices and mobile applications, since it began in 2011. During the development of Swagger, Tony served as the founder and CEO of Reverb, where he led development efforts of the site's innovative word navigation system. Swagger was created in response to a need his development team expressed for a better way to describe REST APIs. After making Swagger open source, Tony was the guiding force that moved the specification forward and created a vibrant enthusiastic community around it. Tony served Wordnik, the world's biggest online English dictionary, by number of words, as VP of Engineering and then CTO, among other roles.
results.name: Java and Web Services:  Using Swagger to Define and Implement APIs

It’s been an action-packed start to 2016 for mobile C# developers. Thanks to recent announcements at Microsoft Build 2016, Xamarin is now included at no extra cost in all Visual Studio subscriptions, including the free Visual Studio Community Edition. Xamarin Evolve 2016 was also full of announcements including exciting additions to Xamarin.Forms, new previews for Xamarin Studio and Visual Studio, the open sourcing of the Xamarin SDKs, and more!

To celebrate, we are teaming up with the Xamarin University team to throw a fantastic Spring Fling to recap all the exciting announcements made at Microsoft Build and Xamarin Evolve, and get some hands-on mobile learning with Xamarin University to help you get started building native mobile apps for iOS, Android, and Windows in C#.

Join us on May 19th for to recap major announcements, enjoy some food and cake, and network with fellow Xamarin developers and engineers.

PARKING: There is construction taking place in the Green Parking Garage which is making parking hard to find. We suggest that your guests park at the 1 Memorial Drive garage and walk back to our 255 Main Street location. It is a short walk, and while the weather might not be optimal, this solution will reduce the amount of time that you are looking for a spot. If you would like to park in the Green Garage and there is a “garage full sign”, we ask that they pull up to the gate and push the intercom located next to the ticket dispense button and identify yourself as a guests of Microsoft.  An attendant will then let you in and direct you to the valet area. If there is no room in valet, they will direct you to the yellow garage.
results.name: Xamarin Evolve Recap & Spring Fling Party

results.description:
Sponsored by AvePoint

Cloud computing has become a very compelling solution for large enterprises looking to reduce total cost of ownership and improve global access to content. For these organizations, while maximizing cloud based technologies like Microsoft Azure or Office 365 can drive better communication and knowledge sharing to help drive productivity, the platform can lose its effectiveness and present compliance risks without proper data governance and compliance. It comes with significant concerns around storing business data outside the walls of their enterprises.

Effective data governance is not only implemented through standardization of processes and education, but defining relevant processes and policies into the technology you provide to your employees. Key considerations include:​

• How do you establish the right level of data governance without compromising workplace efficiency or hindering productivity?

• How do you implement and enforce complex governance policies that can still easily adapt to the changing needs of your organization?

• How do you integrate information security and privacy standards into governance policies to minimize compliance risks and violations?

Join SharePoint MVP Dux Raymond Sy in this interactive session focused on how to adopt an effective data governance strategy and effectively implement proven tactics & winning strategies to ensure your cloud investment is successfully meeting business needs.
results.name: Drive Business Value with Winning Data Governance and Compliance Strategies

results.description:
Greetings Boston Javascript and Node.JS Development Community!

I'm writing to you exactly one week after an AMAZING meetup at Autodesk in Seaport.  We broke all records for the amount of attendees, topping over 90 guests for the evening. I'd like to thank our host, Autodesk, as well as our absolutely top-notch speakers for the evening. Thank you to Jamie, Ian, and Gregor - I think you really helped to up the quality of talks for our meetup. Slide decks will be uploaded to the site shortly, and photos from the event can be found here: http://www.meetup.com/Node-JS-Boston/photos/26909341/

For our May meetup we are back at Autodesk, with an all-star lineup of speakers with a focus on Node.JS operations and security.  Right off the plane from London and recent talks at O'Reilly Fluent and London Node Users Group, Guy Podjarny will talk about Node security.  Erik Dasque will be speaking about Docker anti-patterns with Node.JS in mind. And regarding everyone's favorite topic - IoT - Paul Boss will cover IoT security talking about recent attacks, news, and how to go about protecting your devices and your platforms and applications.

Same as the April meetup, Autodesk will graciously be providing pizza, wine and beer (from the Harpoon brewery across the street!) as well as the space which turned out to be perfect for our group in April. I look forward to seeing all of you in a few weeks!  Let me know if you have any question - message me on the meetup site.  See you soon!

Brian

----

Guy Podjarny 
Stranger danger: Addressing the security risk in npm dependencies

Open source modules, and especially npm, are undoubtedly awesome. However, they also represent an undeniable and massive risk. You’re introducing someone else’s code into your system, often with little or no scrutiny. Each component may have vulnerabilities (~14% of them do), be compromised, or even be outright malicious. Multiply that risk by hundreds of dependencies, and you have a recipe for disaster.

We will demonstrate how you can mitigate this risk without losing productivity. We will also share data about risk, show how to find and fix known vulnerabilities in these dependencies, discuss how to prioritize the ones worthy of manual inspection, and suggest what to monitor in production.

Guy Podjarny (@guypod) is a cofounder at Snyk.io focusing on the security risk in your dependencies. Guy was previously CTO at Akamai and founder of Blaze.io, and worked on the first web app firewall, security static analysis tool. Guy is a frequent conference speaker, the author of "Responsive & Fast”, “High Performance Images” and the upcoming “Securing Third Party Code” (via O’Reilly), and the creator of Mobitest. 

Erik Dasque
Docker anti-patterns with Node.JS

In this talk, I will explore three Docker anti-patterns I stumbled on in my own journey towards Docker nirvana, using Node.JS. Through studying these, we’ll develop better understanding of containerization. The goal is to provide attendees with a solid understanding of the reason for and the nature of containers.

Erik (@edasque) is a senior director of engineering at Constant Contact, were manage the teams that build most of the customer-facing products including the federating Toolkit offering, email marketing, marketing automation, coupon and events. Before that, Erik was the CTO at Nutraclick, as the CTO, Vice President of Product Development at the Vivaki Nerve Center and the Vice President of Engineering for BzzAgent. Erik never stops to learn and recently tackled diverse projects using AWS, Docker, mobile development with Swift, node.js & Go. Every year, Erik organizes the free, invitation only, e4e developer conference in Waltham.


Paul Boss
IoT and Smart Device Security

Gartner has estimated that 21 billion internet-connected devices will be in the hands of consumers by 2020. As the Internet of Things becomes more ubiquitous, we see “dumb” devices becoming “smart” as they call for internet connectivity as part of normal day-to-day use. As internet-connected versions of devices like thermostats, syringe pumps, and centrifuges become commercially successful, we’re finding that little thought has gone into securing the data collected or controlled by them. When considering everyday objects like refrigerators and toasters, the risk is arguably limited. But consider the ramifications when products that bear the keys to our life & livelihood, devices like cars and pacemakers, are compromised. How “smart” are these devices if they are more often than not susceptible to potentially lethal attacks? 

In this talk we will explore: Recent, successful IoT attacks A first-hand account working with an early-stage company to identify potentially dangerous vulnerabilitiesHow to take a proactive approach to security: what we can do moving forward to keep ourselves safe from “smart” devices? 

Paul Boss (@BossXL) is a software engineer with experience designing and developing web applications. He is focused on event-driven applications, with a knack for finding thought-out, long lasting solutions for everyday problems. Paul is passionate about building applications from the ground up with great design and development, as well as exploring new ways to make connections through past experience and new research.

results.description:
The Boston Traders Meetup will be hosting a monthly options meeting to discuss options trading. This will be an informal gathering of folks who trade options who would like to share their knowledge and learn from each other. 


Beginners and experienced traders are welcome.


This event will be held on the Thursday evening before the monthly expiration Friday.* Holding the meeting at monthly expiration will allow people to discuss the trades that they have put on during the prior month and perhaps to share ideas for trades to put on in the next month. For weekly options traders, the monthly expiry is of little significance unto itself, but for the monthly options traders, it will hold more significance.

Mary-Lou Drozek will be moderating this meeting. She has been trading options for about 5 years and is happy to share ideas.

The meeting location is Panera Bread in Quincy, which has wifi and is visible from the North Quincy T stop on the Red Line. The location could possibly change, so please check back with the event page just to confirm the location before heading off to the meeting.

-------------------------------------------


* Meetup allows for scheduling "the third Thursday of the month," but not the "Thursday before the third Friday of the month," which is what we need. Using the Meetup scheduling system alone without intervention would mean that the third Thursday will be on expiration week except for those months starting on a Friday, as is the case in August of 2014; in which case, the meeting would fall a week after the monthly expiry week. We believe that we will be able to successfully manipulate this consideration in the meetup system to keep the meetings all on the Thursday evening before expiration Friday. If you see a meeting time that isn't the Thursday evening before expiration Friday, please let us know and we will correct it. Thank you.

Java and Web Services: Using Swagger to Define and Implement APIs

Swagger can provide beautiful documentation for your web service, but also defines a powerful interface. With the right tooling, that interface can be used to auto generate client SDKs and even servers. In this talk, we’ll use open-source and SAAS tools to generate both client and server implementations so you can worry about your business logic instead of web service plumbing.

Tony Tam
Vice President of Products, Swagger

Tony Tam has been the driving force behind Swagger, the leading API description format used by developers in almost every modern programming language and deployment environment to design and deliver APIs that fuel IoT, microservices and mobile applications, since it began in 2011. During the development of Swagger, Tony served as the founder and CEO of Reverb, where he led development efforts of the site's innovative word navigation system. Swagger was created in response to a need his development team expressed for a better way to describe REST APIs. After making Swagger open source, Tony was the guiding force that moved the specification forward and created a vibrant enthusiastic community around it. Tony served Wordnik, the world's biggest online English dictionary, by number of words, as VP of Engineering and then CTO, among other roles.
results.name: Java and Web Services: Using Swagger to Define and Implement APIs

results.description:
Walkers & Joggers Welcome

May 3, 2016 @ 6:15PM (every Tuesday and Thursday night for 9 wks)

We're here to help you achieve your goal of beginning to run your first 5K. Too many people have been turned off of running simply by trying to start off too fast. Their bodies rebel, and they wind up miserable, wondering why anyone would possibly want to run in the first place. You should ease into your 5K training plan gradually. In fact, the beginners' program we outline here is less of a running regimen than a walking and jogging program. The idea is to transform you from couch potato to runner, getting you to begin running a 5K or 3.1 miles and on a regular basis in just two months.  Each session should take about 20 or 30 minutes, three times a week. That just happens to be the same amount of moderate exercise recommended by numerous studies for optimum fitness. This program will get you fit. 

We will be meeting twice a week, so you SHOULD train the 3rd time on your own either on Saturday or Sunday to keep with the schedule.  Remember to bring your sneakers and some water.
  http://www.coolrunning.com/engine/2/2_3/181.shtml


Inclement Weather: Heavy rains will cancel. We will train if it is overcast or there is a slight drizzle. Please plan to bring a lightweight jacket with a hood just in case.

4/29/2016 Unfortunately, the original speaker, David Quinn was not able to make this event, Mark Goloboy has graciously stepped in to speak about Accounting Based Marketing and Agile Marketing instead. 

Agile Methodology is used within the Marketing team, but what about efforts that span departments? Account Based Marketing (ABM) requires coordination between marketing managers, sales leadership, account managers, and marketing agencies. Mark Goloboy, a digital marketing strategist, will show you how to apply an agile methodology to ABM efforts. He will share ABM approaches, success stories, and sample deliverables from his work at EMC, AspenTech, and Monster. 

This talk will complement Mark's discussion at the SAMI Breakfast meetup earlier on May 19th. If you are interested in hearing about the benefits of ABM for aligned Sales and Marketing efforts, and discussing ABM with an executive level Sales and Marketing audience, please also plan to attend that meeting.http://www.meetup.com/Sales-and-Marketing-Innovators/events/230728289/

Mark Goloboy walks the line between marketing, sales, and technology and helps companies develop successful go-to-market approaches. His expertise in demand generation, marketing technology, and digital marketing helps him align sales and marketing processes. Mark’s background includes marketing strategy, technology, operations, and analytics leadership roles at EMC, AspenTech, and Monster. Mark started his career as a Data Warehouse and Business Intelligence technology consultant at Accenture, and moved into marketing while building customer databases for Harte-Hanks' largest Financial Services clients. Mark enjoys discussing customer acquisition and retention challenges and developing creative strategies with revenue focused executives.

results.description:
Bro is a stateful, protocol-aware, open source, high-speed network monitor with applications such as a next generation intrusion detection system, real-time network discovery tool, historical network analysis tool, real-time network intelligence, and more. With a powerful event-based programming language at its core, the Bro Platform ships with powerful frameworks-signature detection, the ability to extract and analyze files, and the capability to integrate massive amounts of local and external intel—all at incredibly high rates.

This tutorial focuses on helping you understand some of the many tasks that you can accomplish with the Bro Platform using a hands-on container based training environment. Beginning with an introduction to the Bro Platform, this fast-paced tutorial helps experienced network operators quickly get up to speed on leveraging the technology. Students work with traffic samples of distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, deploy large sets of threat intelligence, analyze compromised host traffic, dynamically generate streaming network analytics, and more.

Students should be well versed in TCP/IP and networking fundamentals and come prepared with a workstation (Linux, Windows or Mac) with an SSH client to connect to the training environment.

Speaker Bio

Liam Randall, CEO, Critical Stack
Liam (@Hectaman) founded Critical Stack to containerize security infrastructure. He has focused on end-user training, application development and advanced NSM at large scale. A frequent speaker at security conferences you can usually find him training users on the Bro Platform at workshops, conferences or online.
results.name: Workshop: Introduction to NSM leveraging Bro

results.description:
Come join us for a lively book discussion - Mountains Beyond Mountains by Tracy Kidder


This compelling and inspiring book  shows how one person can work wonders. In Mountains Beyond Mountains, Pulitzer Prize—winning author Tracy Kidder tells the true story of a gifted man who loves the world and has set out to do all he can to cure it.

In medical school, Paul Farmer found his life’s calling: to cure infectious diseases and to bring the lifesaving tools of modern medicine to those who need them most. Kidder’s magnificent account takes us from Harvard to Haiti, Peru, Cuba, and Russia as Farmer changes minds and practices through his dedication to the philosophy that “the only real nation is humanity.” At the heart of this book is the example of a life based on hope and on an understanding of the truth of the Haitian proverb “Beyond mountains there are mountains”–as you solve one problem, another problem presents itself, and so you go on and try to solve that one too.

“Mountains Beyond Mountains unfolds with a force of gathering revelation,” says Annie Dillard, and Jonathan Harr notes, “[Paul Farmer] wants to change the world. Certainly this luminous and powerful book will change the way you see it.”

This event is free, but please support the group and the event location by purchasing a drink, snack or lite bite. Please do not bring outside food or drinks into Coffee Loft.

Please be considerate and change your RSVP if you cannot attend!!
