May 20th -  Biodanza  Based on anthropological studies of dance and traditional rituals celebrating life, Biodanza stimulates community, awakens a consciousness for universal solidarity, enhances participants’ joy and vitality and celebrates the sacredness of life.

Biodanza allows participants to further their connection to themselves  as well as others, and to develop their sense of identity through the uniqueness of their dances.  It fosters spontaneous, playful and vital self-expression and moving, sincere encounters with other participants.

Biodanza was developed in the 60’s in Chile by anthropologist, psychologist, poet and painter Rolando Toro.  It is practiced in over 60 countries, all around the globe.

Éva Kyzirides has been fueled by a long term passion for dance.  She first studied contemporary dance and worked as a dancer / choreographer for 10 years.  Further, interested in the cultural and social dimension of dance, she completed a Masters’ degree in Dance Ethnology.  She has been teaching Biodanza since 2006.  Biodanza combines her passion for movement with her interest in dance as a means of self-expression, growth and transformation within the human community.

After class enjoy dancing to music by Rose.

Dancers of all ages and abilities are invited to dance barefoot, any way you like, with or without a partner, in a smoke and alcohol free environment. Children are welcome.

Dance Friday is an activity of the non-profit Movement Collective. Suggested Donation: $15 8pm-9:15, $10-15 after 9:30, $5-10 after 11,  under  23 years old $5-15, or donate 45 minutes of your time to help out.  We recommend casual, light-weight, comfortable clothing that you can  move in.

For more information, please call: 6I[masked], go to <a>www.dancefriday.org,</a> or visit us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/#/pages/Dance-Friday/[masked]?ref=ts

AFRO-BEAT

Lamine Touré comes from a long line of griots, a caste of musicians and oral historians among the Wolof people of Senegal. Born into a family of griot percussionists, masters of the sabar drum, Lamine has been drumming since the age of four. Touré showcases his musical talent and versatility on a wide range of percussion instruments, from sabar and djembé to tama (talking drum), as well as in taasu (rhythmic poetry, similar to rap). Since 2002, Lamine Touré has been serving as Artist-in-Residence at the MIT, where he teaches sabar drumming and dance classes.

No cover charge

Fridays, March – mid-November | 8:30 – 10:00 pm
Offering Format: Public Event
Recommended for grades Pre-K – 12 and adults
Museum of Science
Free

Did you know that the Museum offers our starry-eyed public a free evening full of astronomy-themed fun on weather-cooperative Fridays?

Between 8:30pm and 10pm each Friday, weather-permitting, visit the Gilliland Observatory on the roof of the Museum’s parking garage. On clear nights, you can view stars, planets, the Moon, and other astronomical phenomena. On cloudy nights, tour the inside of our Observatory, and participate in astronomy-related activities run by our knowledgeable staff.

This program does not run on nights when the weather is inclement. For more details, and to find out if Astronomy After Hours is running on a given Friday, call our hotline,[masked]-0267. We update each Friday by 5:30pm with the evening’s plans.

Astronomy After Hours runs seasonally, from the first Friday in March to the last Friday before Thanksgiving. Admission is free thanks to the generosity of the Lowell Institute (parking charges still apply).

Thanks to Don Doughty for letting us know about the museum.

Source: http://www.mos.org/public-events/astronomy-after-hours

results.description:
Time for a periodic visit to a unique venue. Lipps usually packs a punch, so a pretty safe bet??

 Lisa Love Experience is a 4-piece band for clubs and a 5-piece band for weddings, private parties and corporate events. We provide an inspired performance with the perfect flow of music from the beginning to the end. During our breaks we keep the music going with one of Lisa's custom Ipod playlists so once we start, the music never stops. 

   Lisa Love Experience is a TRUE band. Lisa Love and Billy Garzone (along with Gabe Cabral and Otis Rogers) formed the Lisa Love Experience 14 years ago with a mission statement: to play great music and entertain the audience as if it were our lifes purpose ...because it is! It's not just the songs we play, but how we play them, with musical inspiration and love for the crowd. Lisa's amazing ability to connect with the audience and make them part of the experience creates much more than a great show, it creates lasting memories. Our reviews are a testament to that. We perform with musical passion, high energy and a love for what we do and most importantly ...a love for the audience.
   
   During the course of our career we have had some absolutely amazing experiences and opportunies, performing well over 1000 shows all over New England and traveling as far as Hawaii. We have been featured in many popular Boston wedding blogs and Boston wedding magazines (Style Me Pretty, Bliss, I Do ...just to name a few). We have also been featured on the televison show Boston Chronicle and New Hampshire Chronicle for thier wedding specials. As much as we love performing in the most inspiring and funnest venues New England has to offer, what we love most is the people we play for.

results.description:
This is the reoccurring meetup for the weekly open water swims at Walden Pond. A well attended venue for triathletes training for races of all distances. 

The gate opens at 7 a.m. and the Parking is right off of Walden St. Walden charges to park a their lot ($5) via a computerized parking attendant that takes cards. I'd recommend the annual pass if you think you're going to come to more meetups. 

We will start swimming at 8:30 a.m. sharp!!

Across and back from the beach (Pictured above) is a little over a mile; a perfect distance for those training for Olympic, 70.3 and Ironman races.

There are also some close to shore routes for people getting better acquainted with open water (see distance maps). We meet near the lifeguard house right on the beach closes to Walden street. Here is the map of walden pond.

1) Always wear your wetsuit. This is for safety above all.

2) Swim in groups if you can. Always match up with someone or a group that swims your pace. 


3) Make certain that you look out for each other. 

4) Don't attempt to swim across the pond if you haven't trained for that distance. The beauty of Walden is that you can swim very close to shallow water and get some good open water training in.

5) If there are people that are looking to go long for the first time, let me know in advance and I may be able to swim angel, or get a swim angel group together. That way we can do it in a controlled and safe environment.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be by the Lifeguard house
results.name: Weekly Walden Open Water Swim

results.description:
We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course (if you go at least 8 miles - 4 out and 4 back).

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM.  We will leave right at 8:30 AM (especially when it is cold out!).

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!

results.description:
• [Don't be concerned if you don't see many RSVPs here... our members tend to RSVP via our members site at WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org.]

Please arrive at 9:00 am. From 9 to 9:15 am, we set up the meeting and network. We start the meeting at 9:15 am, and continue until 10:45 am. When you enter Church of the Good Shepherd, walk downstairs and take a left. If you arrive late, just walk in and have a seat at any open spot.

Please visit "Meeting Roles & Responsibilities" for more information about what to expect from a club meeting.

Here's a sample agenda for our meeting:

9:00 AM Setting up/Networking

9:15 AM President's Greeting and Club announcements

President opens meeting and welcomes guests

Toastmaster's Welcome

Introduces each role, its purpose, and the person who will perform the role.

Humorist/Invocation

Starts the meeting on a light-hearted note.

Grammarian's Word of the Day

Encourages each of us to add a new word to our vocabularies. Challenge us to use the new word spontaneously.

Scheduled Speeches

Club members give the speeches that they've scheduled and prepared in advance using the guidelines from one of the Toastmasters International communication manuals.

Table Topics

Our meeting's Topicsmaster provides our members and guests with an opportunity for demonstrating and honing their skills for impromptu speaking.

General Evaluator's Introduction

Introduces evaluation team members and evaluate the evaluators and the meeting in general.

Speech Evaluations

Club members provide helpful, supportive feedback to each of the scheduled speaker in a positive and friendly manner.

Grammarian's Report

Grammarian reports on how many times speakers used the Word of the Day and how we used the English language.

Ah-Counter's Report

Ah-counter reports how many filler-words and false starts were used by each participant, to raise speakers' awareness of these instances and to encourage improvement.

Timer's Report

Timer reports speaking times of all major speaking roles to encourage members learn to accomplish tasks within set time limits.

General Evaluator's Report

General evaluator provides a review of the meeting, what went well, and areas for improvement to encourage continual growth and an optimal quality of our meetings.

Toastmaster's Closing Remarks

10:45 AM President Adjourns Meeting

We usually have a convivial lunch at The Red Lentil. Hang around after the meeting for details.

WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org

<a href="http://watertownsaturdaytoastmasters.org/"></a>

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to take two days to climb one of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire (Carrigain) and one of the New England Hundred Highest (Nancy).

Day #1 - We will use Nancy Pond Trail to reach Norcross Pond where we will start the short bushwhack up and back to Nancy. From there we will continue along Nancy Pond Trail and Carrigain Notch Trail to reach Stillwater Junction. There we will set up our tents and spend the night.

Day #2 - We will pack up our gear and use Carrigain Notch Trail and Desolation Trail to reach the summit of Carrigain. After relaxing atop the fire tower at the summit we will follow Signal Ridge Trail down to the trailhead.

See What to Bring below for more details.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.


RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 8 people.

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~1.5 MPH) trip we will hike about 17.5 miles and climb about 6,000 feet over the two days.

• Day #1 = About 9.7 miles of hiking and about 3,100 feet of climbing.


• Day #2 = About 7.8 miles of hiking and about 2,900 feet of climbing.


This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.


Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/13-Mt-Carrigain-4700

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.10728781500046&lon=-71.42729825499964#.VzJaEGOwlrU

=== What to Bring === 

There are no established tent sites in this frequently used area so we will be selecting the "best available spot" that the wilderness area offers. The idea is to share tents and group gear like stoves, fuel, and water treatment. You are on your own for all meals - if they consist of anything more complicated than simply boiling water and pouring it into a bag you will need to bring your own supplies.

We might still need traction - be prepared to bring either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons.


Use this link for a list of items needed for a moderate temperature backpack trip: 

• http://files.meetup.com/492954/Moderate_Weather_Backpacking.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at Signal Ridge Trailhead which is located on the southeast side of Sawyer River Road. According to Google Maps this spot is about 172 miles from Boston and it will take about 3 hours 1 minutes to drive there. We will leave a few cars here and then drive to the starting point.

Use this link to get driving directions:

• https://goo.gl/maps/KXfsVBQE9JP2


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.description:
Their major issue is that they have tons of donations, and not even close enough amount of volunteers, to sort useable vs. recycle goods.  

http://thewishproject.org/ 

The Wish Project is a non-profit dedicated to providing free furniture, home goods, baby goods, and clothing to people in need in the Merrimack Valley, primarily through reuse and recycling. They serve thousands of people each year, and rely on the help of many volunteers. Let's be some of those volunteers! We'll take on whatever task they need on this day, but generally it involves sorting and organizing donations so they can be given out to clients. Children ages 8+ are welcome to join the effort. It's a great opportunity to teach your kids compassion in a very hands-on way. 

IMPORTANT:

If you are bringing children, please make a note in the comments section so I can give the Wish Project an accurate count of adults and kids who will be attending.

http://thewishproject.org/

 *PLEASE NOTE:  When you RSVP 'yes' it becomes a commitment. I am in contact with the volunteer coordinator, Patty, whom is now a member, giving her a head count. She then creates a list of things that need to be done -relying upon the number of volunteers. If your plans change, please be considerate -take a moment to update your RSVP to 'no.' It's very simple- and greatly appreciated! Thanks :)
results.how_to_find_us: The WORD is out, n' spreading!
results.name: Giving Back aka Volunteering @ The Wish Project - Lowell

results.description: This is the riding practice session for our basic bicycling class, following up on the classroom session in the evening of May 16 or May 20  -- see other meetup announcements. The morning parking lot session will cover bicycle handling skills: gears and brakes, efficient pedaling, comfort, scanning ahead and behind, signaling, quick turns. We take a short ride to lunch, then continue riding to practice positioning on the street, negotiating right of way, uphill and downhill riding and group riding. You may take a written exam and receive a nationally recognized certificate. Bicycle and helmet are required.
results.how_to_find_us: Enter on the driveway on Wyman Street just south of Lincoln Street and continue until you see the group.

results.description:
In this favorite outing, we will be going to the top of Buck Hill in the Blue Hills, with its 360 panoramic view of the area.  Before that, you'll go through open woods, up some steep, but short, granite "stairs", and over a vernal stream.

One of our favorite hikes!

Activity Level:  Moderate

What to Bring:  Hiking footwear, weather appropriate clothing, water for 3 hours, snacks, bug spray, sunglasses.

Note:  This meetup will always say "full" with only the organizer going.  To reserve your spot, sign up at www.llbean.com/Dedham!

results.description:
Once you register on Southborough Recreation Sports Meetup you can RSVP to play in all the Meetups you want. The $15 per month fee will be collected when you show up to play and will cover you for that month.

Doubles, Mixed Doubles, Singles matches will be played on outdoor hard-courts. All levels 3.0 and higher welcome. You must be able to serve over-head, volley and rally. New tennis balls for each court will be provided.

Based on play level you indicated in your profile initially you will be matched up with similar level players. Adjustment to level may be done based on actual play. Players participating in a session will be emailed the day before with court assignment. You decide on starting teams on each court.

All guests must also register, RSVP and pay the fee to participate. This will ensure we have a spot for your guest...matched to players of similar skill-level.

1st Session matches are from 8:00-8:50AM and 8:50-9:30AM. 2nd Session matches are from 9:30-10:15AM and 10:15-11:00AM. You must RSVP to both sessions if you wish to play from 8AM to 11AM. Matches are w/Ad scoring. Leading team moves up & splits. Other team moves down & splits.

Occasionally, we will have to play at other locations on days ARHS has events. Organizer will change location on the meetup description.

Rain and/or wet courts may force cancellation which will be communicated via e-mail as early as possible.

All players play at their own risk at all times.

Organizers reserve the right to remove any player from the RSVP list or this social tennis Group or the courts at any time for any reason without advance notice.

results.description:
The Greater Boston Food Bank (GBFB) is the largest hunger-relief organization in New England and among the largest food banks in the country. Last year, they distributed more than 54 million pounds of food, enough to provide healthy meals to over 500,000 people.

The GBFB is committed to increasing their food distribution to provide at least one meal a day to every person in need in eastern Massachusetts. GBFB works to acquire, store, organize and distribute food through local food pantries, community meal programs, homeless and residential shelters, youth programs, senior centers, and day-care centers embedded in communities throughout the nine counties of eastern Massachusetts.

Volunteers play a critical role in ending hunger by giving their time and talent to support The Greater Boston Food Bank. Last year, about 26,000 volunteers worked a total of 65,000 hours. Volunteers will be working in the warehouse and inspecting, sorting, and packing food and grocery products.

For more information, please visit the GBFB's official website: http://gbfb.org/
results.name: Greater Boston Food Bank

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!
results.how_to_find_us: On the triangle between the two fields, just off the bike path and roughly in line with the parking lot.
results.name: (Arlington) - Intermediate Swordplay, Dagger and Grappling

group.name: Boston Armizare -- Historical Swordplay and More!

results.description:
We will meet to play Ultimate Frisbee on Saturday morning from 10 AM - 12 PM at Kendall Square Field in East Cambridge (at the intersection of Third St. and Rogers St.). There is free parking at the Kennedy-Longfellow School parking lot on weekends. We welcome players of all skill levels!

We ask that our members RSVP for the game so we know we have enough people for a game. We will confirm by Friday night 9PM or earlier whether the game is on or not. By RSVP'ing, you also allow us to alert you of last-minute cancellations (usually weather related).

10:00-10:15 AM - Warm up, stretch, and practice. Overview rules and divide into teams.
10:15 AM - Game starts.
Post-game - Hang out, grab lunch.

Please dress appropriately for a game of competitive Ultimate Frisbee. We recommend that you bring white and dark-colored t-shirts so that we can divide into two teams easily. Bring your own water, and we will provide the discs and cones. Come join us for Ultimate Frisbee and make new friends in the process!

Tennis courts are always limited. We have to be respectful and not take up all the courts. We usually get 2-3 courts for our group.

results.description:
An RSVP only indicates your interest in the sail!

While an RSVP is necessary for me to track your interest, it does not guarantee a spot on the boat. I will send you an email to confirm your spot on the boat. This will be an e-mail directly from me, please do not be confused by system generated e-mails confirming your spot! Describing your sailing experience in detail when prompted during the RSVP process will increase your chances of being selected.


To expect

Moderate winds and cool temperatures. Please dress appropriately. You may get splashed and will be asked to hike out w/o the benefit of rails or hiking straps.  I like to sail fast so be prepared to frequently trim the sails and adjust boat balance. Sailing experience preferred but not essential. I need at least 1 person able to steer w/o supervision. This will be a 3 to 4 hour sail with no pit stops on a boat without a head or engine.  You should not be susceptible to seasickness under moderate conditions or bring appropriate medication.

Where we'll sail

To be decided based on conditions.

What we will sail on
Sonar (http://piersparksailing.org/aboutus/our-fleet-and-equipment). This is a 23 foot racer/daysailer with no head, cabin or engine.

To bring
There is plenty of dry storage so bring extra layers, food, water, and medicine if you get sea sick. PFDs will be provided.

Important Disclaimer

Sailing with me may be stressful at times. It is unlikely but is possible to sustain an injury during sailing. I will try to ensure that we have a safe sailing adventure but be advised that getting scratched or hurt occasionally is considered part of the sport.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet by the head of the ramp down to the dock
results.name: Sailing a Sonar in Boston Harbor.

results.description:
Let's take a relaxed ride out to the Cordova Sculpture Garden in Lincoln. 

Art, nature, and a sunny ride, what's not to like. 

We'll start at Alewife T station , amble out through Belmont, Lexington, Lincoln, to the sculpture garden.   Bikes are free entrance.   After visiting the sculptures we will loop through Concord and Lexington, for a total distance of 30 miles.

The average page will be about 10-12 mph moving - this ride is built for comfort, not for speed!  I expect we'll take about an hour to get there, spend an hour visiting, and about two hours to get back, for four hours total.   We should be back closer to 2pm than 3pm, but flat tires happen...

The detailed itinerary is at http://www.strava.com/routes/5053705
results.how_to_find_us: Gather at the end of the minuteman on the northwest corner of the station.  There's a tiny pond there.
results.name: Bike to Cordova Sculpture Garden

results.description:
Another free shoot day! Vander Photography has successfully made this an annual event.

This event is open to photographers, models, cosplayers, hair stylists, makeup artists, any and all creative minds, groups, families, and anyone else who wants to have free shoots done! Vander Photography will bring a blanket and find a nice spot for people to sit and relax when they aren't shooting. Otherwise, run around through the gardens, the theater district or Chinatown and shoot your life away.

The Rules from last year:
- Besides the rare candids, any photographer(s) and subject(s) need to agree to shooting before it happens.
- If, for some reason, someone doesn't want to work with you, go find someone else to have fun with! Everyone can have a good time!
- Bring something for peeps to share. Munchkins for some snacking, fruit for a healthy day, gum to keep breath in order. Even if it's a cheap, bulk item that cost $5, join the community with a small, generous offering. It breaks the ice and everyone automatically loves you. I'll probably bring a few dozen waters and a cooler so people don't dehydrate.
- No Hate. This is mainly for people who work in similar fields who may not like each other, whether its rival photography companies or on the modeling/cosplaying circuit. Just enjoy the day with the other people there.
To keep up with the latest details also join the Facebook event page at:

https://www.facebook.com/events/932177043577309/
results.how_to_find_us: Go to the event page on Facebook, https://www.facebook.com/events/932177043577309/ , click on "See All Posts" and there's a photo map posted there.

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It's that easy.

Breakfast Details : Between 11:15 and 11:30 (depending on how long we run) we will meet back at Eastern Mountain Sports on Commonwealth Ave. near Packards Corner for Pot Luck style brunch.

Contribute to a great breakfast with an item to share with the group (eggs, bagels, fruits, muffins, juice, bacon, potatoes, etc.) You're not obligated to bring anything, though, so please join us for breakfast after the run anyway.

ALL ABILITY LEVELS WELCOME!!!

Secret parking is accessible in the Star Market parking lot (just make sure you walk through Star Market. No one has ever been towed.)

Bring a friend, see you out there.


informalrunning.com


Read the BLOG

Every Saturday morning at 10:00 AM we gather for a fun, calming group run at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. Both walkers and runners are welcome. Our main goal is to socialize and support one another!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 AM and Thursday evenings at 6:30 PM. We first gather in front of the Cleveland Circle Starbucks, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there!

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

results.description:
What Will We Do?:   We will trek about 6.5  miles of the trails along the ridges circumlocuting the reservation perimeter to the top of 435' Cedar Hill (see above pic) and through a boulder strewn chasm on the Hemlock Knoll Trail.  We'll also cross Hartford Street to trek  atop an esker running through the swamp land of the Fork Factory Brook, where we'll visit the site of an old mill with its own canal.  The terrain is generally moderate with wide trails but there are some steep sections as well as rocks, big tree roots, gravel and wet leaves underfoot. Our anticipated walking pace is 2.5- 3.0 miles per hour.

There are many picnic tables for those that wish to join for a picnic lunch after the hike.

Please do not talk your cell phone (except for emergencies), listen to the radio or play music during the hike.


There is a $5.00 fee if not a member of Trustees Reservation.  They do not have a computer so they can't look you up if you don't have your card.  It is payable at a machine. You can become a member of the Trustees on-line by going to http://www.thetrustees.org/membership/

What to Bring?:-- Water (2 liters), lunch/snacks, hiking boots (not sneakers or trail runners), and bug spray with DEET. Please be familiar with the information contained in What You Need To Know About Lyme Tick Infection  in the Pages section.

No dogs  and no guests.  If you want to bring someone on this hike, have them join the group so they can sign the liability waiver. Everyone attending this and all Trekker events must be a group member who has signed up beforehand. There are no exceptions.

By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below: 
Remember: I am a volunteer. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

For more information, a printable trail map and driving directions please go to:

http://www.thetrustees.org/places-to-visit/greater-boston/rocky-woods.html


For a description of another Rocky Wooods hike, check out: http://www.hikenewengland.com/RockyWoodsMA080602.html


If you are offering or need a ride or would like to carpool, post a message in the comment section.  To respond to a ride posting, please send that person a direct message by clicking on their profile picture on the right. For your own safety, please  the "Message" function to make your arrangements in private and off the comment board. Also (for your safety), please do not post your phone # on the message board.
results.name: Hike Rocky Woods , Medfield Trustees Reservation

We're going to teach real estate agents an alternative to working with the traditional home buyer and why working with real estate investors can be a more productive use their time. Topics discussed will include:


1. What the traditional real estate agent does and why so many of them fail.
2. Why building relationships w/ real estate investors can double or triple your income.

6. Cash flow (buy & hold) vs. Flip Investors - What's the best way to crunch the numbers?

results.description:
Wanna try us out? Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary.


• First two practices are $10 (The $10 can go towards the full membership of $110 for the rest of the season). Pay via Paypal here: "Boston 1 - Join us"

• Also you will not be allowed on the boats if you do not sign the waiver: "Boston 1 e-waiver"


• Make sure to check our Facebook, </a><a href="http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook">http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook for practice announcements and cancellations -- especially in the early and later parts of season with potentially colder night practices. 

Weekly practices are every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday unless a race is scheduled or practice is cancelled.

Mon & Wed: 5:45pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.
Sat: 10:45am - 1pm, meet 10.45am on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.

Optional dinner/lunch or social activity afterwards!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather and water! Be prepared to get wet!

• Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.


• Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.


• Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen. Expensive glasses or sunglasses are not recommended. 


All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locked locker provided on-site. Please bring as little as possible to practice as space is limited.

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Restroom: Do not use the restrooms in the Barking Crab, use the public restrooms near the Daily Catch

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
This is our 9th anniversary Meetup. We'll do the swaps from April as well as May, and maybe some other activities as well! 

ATC THEMES:


1. Imaginary garden.


2. Artist's Choice (anything goes)

We'll also do the April ATC themed swap ("What I Know Now...") at this Meetup.


DEMO/ACTIVITY:  Monoprints!  Martha will provide materials and directions for printing with melted crayon (if it's warm enough to have windows or doors open) and maybe another technique or two!


WHAT OTHER SUPPLIES SHOULD I BRING? There's a suggested list in "All About the NE ATC+ Meetup" (also at the top of the Message Board). But even if you show up empty-handed, that's fine--we have loaner tools.

POTLUCK LUNCH: You're invited, but certainly not required, to bring food or drink for our potluck lunch, or to just bring your own lunch. No need to sign up; bring whatever you like. Please remember that you must take, give away, or throw away any food you bring; we can't leave ANYTHING behind.

FREE STUFF/SALE ITEMS: You're welcome to bring items to give away or sell to other Meetup members onsite. But anything that doesn't get taken or sold needs to go home with you. 

COST: $10, regardless of when you arrive or depart; it covers our costs for the day. Sorry, no partial payments or IOUs. Cash is preferred; small bills are greatly appreciated. You can break large bills in business on Route 135 near the church. If payment is a hardship, please let the organizer know--we can work it out.

RSVPs: Please RSVP "yes" to attend; that way, we'll have an approximate headcount, and you'll receive all notifications about the Meetup! If your plans change, and you will be unable to attend, please change your RSVP to "no" no later than 24 hours before the start of the Meetup, so we'll know not to expect you. Anyone who cancels within 24 hours, regardless of the reason, will need to pay the fee anyway to help cover our costs for the day. 

LAST-MINUTE UPDATES: Please check your email in box and the website before leaving for the Meetup. That way, in the unlikely event that we need to cancel due to bad weather or any other reason, you'll be sure to get the news.

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
Queridos amigos,

Me he enterado de que hacer picknick en el Arboretum está "oficialmente" prohibido.  Además, está claro que, para muchas personas, llegar a un lugar más céntrico sería más cómodo.  De modo que, os propongo que el sábado a las 12:00 nos encontremos en Boston Common delante de la boca del metro Park Street (línea roja y verde) para comentar el libro.  A las 12:20 partiremos parque adentro para encontrar un sitio tranquilo para comentar el libro.  Os animo a que traigáis comida (bocadillos o lo que os apetezca) y toallas/mantas. 

Espero que este lugar sea de vuestro agrado.  El pronostico meteorológico prevé en día nublado y brumoso: un ambiente digno de nuestros queridos citaucas.  No se prevé lluvia.  Pero en el poco probable caso en que llueva por la mañana, nos reuniremos en Schoenhof´s. 

Hasta el sábado!

Un fuerte abrazo y feliz viernes,

Mark

P.D. - Se espera que los ejemplares de "Los afectos" lleguen a Schoenhof´s el próximo miércoles.
results.how_to_find_us: Nos encontraremos delante de la boca del metro "Park Street"
results.name: En mayo: Picknick en Boston Common con "La piel fría" de Albert Sánchez Piñol

results.description:
We'll gather for our final 'Saturday Lunch and Discussion' of the Fall-to-Spring 2016 series (before our Summer Solstice event) at our traditional location in the Parlor at Phillips Brooks House at Harvard University. We'll have a light buffet lunch (sandwiches, salads) provided by GBH at 12:30 pm.

JOE GERSTEIN will lead a discussion at 1:30 on "Our Responsibilities to the World's Indigenous Peoples"

Indigenous peoples have been decimated, relocated or obliterated on every inhabited continent, and their cultures pulverized. However, there are still a few left. What is the answer to providing them with a decent life or even survival? 
Many approaches have been taken after the initial destruction from first contacts with invading peoples. Assimilation hasn't worked. Isolation has not yielded clear positive results. Forced removal has been a disaster. Citizenship hasn't protected them. Political recognition and participation hasn't worked. Apologies haven't worked. What are the appropriate question and answers?

Joe Gerstein will introduce the subject with emphasis on the Australian Aboriginals. Then let's have an energetic discussion. 


Free Parking in Littauer Lot: Enter Maxwell Dworkin Science Quadrangle from Oxford St. and weave your way to the end of the road which is the Littauer Lot, between the Law School Library and the Science Center.
results.name: May Lunch and Discussion, "Our Responsibilities to Earth's Indigenous Peoples"

Disrupt You!: Master Personal Transformation, Seize Opportunity, and Thrive in the Era of Endless Innovation[img src="https://s.evbuc.com/https_proxy?url=http%3A%2F%2Fir-na.amazon-adsystem.com%2Fe%2Fir%3Ft%3Dstartupsinnov-20%26l%3Das2%26o%3D1%26a%3D1250059372&sig=ADR2i79bBlG3YKFuTRHmi2mOmoHlbjY3Bg" alt="">

About Jay Samit

About Jay Samit

Described by Wired as having "the coolest job in the industry" and "a new media guru and Internet pioneer" by the Economic Times, author Jay Alan Samit is a dynamic entrepreneur and intrapreneur who is widely recognized as one of the world's leading experts on disruption and innovation. He launches billion dollar businesses, transforms entire industries, revamps government institutions, and for over three decades continues to be at the forefront of global trends.

Everyone from the Pope to the President calls on Samit to orchestrate positive change in this era of endless innovation. Samit helped grow pre-IPO companies such as Linkedin, held senior management roles at Sony and Universal Studios, pioneered breakthrough advancements in mobile video, internet advertising, ecommerce, social networks, ebooks, and digital music that are used by billions of consumers every day. Samit accurately predicts the future because he is constantly working with those who create it.

An adjunct professor at USC, Samit teaches innovation at America's largest engineering school and is author of the forthcoming book "Disrupt Yourself: Master Personal Transformation, Seize Opportunity, and Thrive in the Era of Endless Innovation" (MacMillan June 2015). He is a regular contributor to the Wall Street Journal and host of its documentary series WSJ Startup of the Year. Samit frequently appears on ABC, Bloomberg, CBS, CNN, Fox, MSNBC, NBC and tweets daily motivation to the over 100,000 business professionals who follow him on twitter @jaysamit. An expert on transformational corporate change, Samit has been quoted in The New York Times, The Economist, Businessweek, Forbes, Los Angeles Times, USA Today, Fast Company and TechCrunch.

Open to singles and couples ages 18+ (adults of all genders)

Follow this link to register for Edible Mushroom Cultivation and don't forget to RSVP on this Meetup page too.

This workshop will introduce participants to the fascinating realm of mushroom cultivation. We will cover cultivating shiitake mushrooms on logs, wine caps on wood chips and oyster mushrooms on straw. Participants will learn how to bring fungi into their gardens and be able to FEAST on mushrooms. 

All participants will take home an inoculated shiitake log AND a oyster fruiting kit.

About Willie Crosby: Willie has been growing mushrooms in a variety of methods for the last four years. He is a co-founder of Fungi Ally and is involved with research, education, and mushroom production. Through study and experience Willie hopes to continue learning the diverse methods people can improve themselves and the world through allying with fungi!

About iFarm: ifarm utilizes a restored 19th century farmstead to reconnect the individual with the earth. The goal is to provide diverse educational experiences that utilize core values of sustainability, rejuvenation, and thoughtful design which both individuals and communities can incorporate into their own environment, experiences and life.

results.description:
The Town of Concord and the National Park Service is hosting "Open House Day" at the historical "Old Manse" on Monument Street -- just outside Concord Center -- as a celebration of its 125th Birthday!

The grounds are beautiful with big old trees and stone walls, the "Old North Bridge" is a stone's throw across a field, and there should be plenty of people strolling and hanging out on the lawns. Apparently, books and blankets for reading on the lawn will be provided – so we may have relatively stationary models on the lawn to sketch. And there’s the big Old Manse to sketch as well – interiors and facades. If you’re interested, there will be self-guided tours with interpreters in each room that you can go to before or after we meet, sketch and share. 


Background Information about the day:
Situated near the banks of the Concord River, the Old Manse is located adjacent to Concord's Old North Bridge, where the Revolutionary War began on April 19, 1775. The Old Manse is a must-see stop on any visit to historic Concord. This National Historic Landmark was built in 1770 by Ralph Waldo Emerson’s grandfather, the Reverend William Emerson [masked]). This Minister's House subsequently became a focal point of America’s political, literary and social revolutions over the course of the next century. Here, Ralph Waldo Emerson [masked]) and Nathaniel Hawthorne [masked]) would draft some of their most famous works. Enjoy free admission during the open house, stroll the beautiful 6-acre landscape and take advantage of 15% off in The Old Manse's Specialty Bookshop.
results.how_to_find_us: In front of the Old Manse.
results.name: Let's pray for good weather and meetup for some sketching at the Old Manse

results.description:
Sign up for free Parent-Baby Infant Massage Class in Watertown May 21, 22 and 23rd, 2016
Please fill this form out to confirm your participation in this free infant massage class.
INFANT MASSAGE is a great way to connect to your baby. Studies have shown infant massage can help babies sleep better, gain weight, reduce fussiness, improve health and relax. Parents who massage their babies often experience increased closeness to and understanding of their infants, reduced stress and post-natal depression, and simply enjoy a wonderful experience with their child and with other parents.

WHAT TO BRING: Bring your baby and your partner, if available. This is a great class for fathers! Pack a towel or baby blanket you do not mind getting oil on, and a change of diapers and clothes. You will be the only one massaging your baby.

LOCATION & DATES:
Watertown Center for Healing Arts

results.description:
{Do you seek greater inner peace?  Peacemakers is a group that helps you look at what "peace" means to you and helps you find how to create more peace in your life.} 

Our Topic This Evening Will ....

... provide you an opportunity to let go of tension, upset, and judgements so that you can experience greater peace.

Many of us have accepted living with tensions in our bodies, with upsets spoiling our mood at unexpected times, with judgments sneaking in. 

Come join us as we practice living our lives more peacefully. 

Peace is not being passive, submissive or indifferent. Peace is an active consciousness that we can learn to enter into, enriching our individual lives, our social situations and the world at large. 

During this evening, we will practice discovering the peace that is always present within us -- no matter what else is going on inside us or outside us in the world.   As we practice recognizing our inner core of peace, we become increasingly able to choose to live in that consciousness of inner peace, even at difficult times of our lives. 

We will look at where we unconsciously practice "against-ness", and learn to let go of that feeling of against-ness, to better work with reality and with the people who surround us. As we let go of "against-ness", we also let go of the upset feelings, prejudices, judgments, tenseness, etc. 

This meeting is sponsored by the Institute of Individual and World Peace (www.iiwp.org)

To Prepare ....

1) When do you feel "against-ness"? 


2) What are the physical signs of your against-ness? (e.g., tightness in throat)  

3) What emotional signs or mental beliefs could be signs of against-ness?

4) How could you be more effective if you were in peace even when bad things happened?

Our Leaders This Afternoon

David Jenkins aspires to live his life more and more in peace. He considers himself a student of living the four principles of peace in his life. This is his highest priority. He is overjoyed to have been involved with the Peacemaker Project for several years. It expands peace in a quiet, loving way, one person at a time.

Emily Page delights in finding joy with others and as an inner process one moment at a time.She's been assisting with Boston Area PeaceMaker Meetings because the simple tools shared go so deep, work so fast and foster such harmony between participants, one session after another. 


Philosophy: The philosophy grounding this work is the realization that peace must start with the individual. One can not fight for peace. If we are going to be a conduit for peace, we must start with ourselves and be in peace. Peace is defined as the absence of againstness. If we can be in peace without being against ourselves or others or situations and encourage others to do the same, then we can be a conduit for peace. 

Facilitators Motivation: We aspire to live our lives more and more in peace. This intention is our highest priority. Participating in these meetings is one way to learn to live our lives more and more in peace. Encouraging others to do the same is strengthening for us all.
results.name: Live In Peace (Peacemakers): let go of tension & upsets into more well being

results.description:
Hi all,

Porchfest is an annual Somerville event where Somerville folks get out on their porches and play music, yes, live music! All over Somerville! We will not be playing music, we'll be meandering around the streets between Porter and Davis Squares listening.


We will meet outside Porter Square Books at 2:00, and begin our walk through Somerville from there. There are a couple acts this group has enjoyed from past years that we'll plan to visit, but after that we'll just wander around. This is very casual event. So we begin by crossing Elm St and heading up Hancock St toward Charnwood Rd. Here we'll see the Charnwood Porchpickers (I could listen to them ALL day) and a thereminist named Jon Bernhardt.

If there is a particular band you wish to see, please bring the address and we'll try to swing by. I'll have my Android handy so we can easily find our way.

Also, if any of you wish to join but need to meet us later, please private message me and I'll give you my phone number. I can't promise we'll be able to find each other, but we can try. Sometimes the bands are QUITE loud and I won't hear my phone/text ring. And the group may be on the move and so difficult to find. But again, I am willing to at least try!

Oh, how I LOVE this event! Looking forward to seeing you all.


------------------

Musicians who participate in Porchfest register with their band name, the type of music they play, the address of their porch, and possibly the time slot in which they are playing. You can find that information and more here:  http://www.thebostoncalendar.com/events/somerville-porchfest-2016

results.description:
Me Before You by Jojo Moyes

"They had nothing in common until love gave them everything to lose...  Louisa Clark is an ordinary girl living an exceedingly ordinary life, steady boyfriend, close family who has barely been farther afield than their tiny village.  She takes a badly needed job working for ex Maste of the Universe Will Traynor, who is wheelchair bound after an accident.  Will has always lived a huge life big deals, extreme sports, worldwide travel and now he's pretty sure he cannot live the way he is.  Will is acerbic, moody, bossy but Lou refuses to treat him with kid gloves, and soon his happiness means more to her than she expected.  When she learns that Will has shocking plans of his own, she sets out to show him that life is still worth living."

Come join us to discuss this romantic love story before the movie comes out June 3, 2016

results.description:
Click Here for a Free Online Webinar: https://www.innerengineering.com/online/free-meditation-webinars-2?signinsrc=Meetup-Boston

Isha Kriya Guided Meditation- 

A lot of people find it really difficult to calm the mind and settle the body for meditation when they first try it. Too many people get frustrated and give up on meditation before they can experience its many benefits.

These 1-hour guided sessions offer a simple, but powerful kriya practice that aligns your mind, body, and inner-energies to easily and naturally become meditative. Once meditative, your experience of the life within you and the world around you becomes much deeper and richer. Daily activity becomes effortless and joyful. 

You can easily learn this 12-to-18 minute Isha Kriya process in one session and practice on your own, or return to class to ask questions and deepen the experience with the group. Benefits of regular practice include improving health, energy and vitality; enhancing mental focus, memory and clarity; reducing stress and establishing a deep sense of peace and inner balance.

Isha Kriya is a gentle, seated practice, which can be practiced in a chair. No previous meditation experience is necessary.

The Isha Kriya process was developed by realized yogi, Sadhguru Vasudev. Sadhguru is renowned for his powerful yoga and meditation programs, as well as thriving humanitarian initiatives. He has been hosted to speak and offer meditations at numerous global leadership forums, businesses and universities, including the United Nations, the World Economic Forum, the British House of Lords, TED, MIT, and the World Peace Congress.

This free session will be facilitated by a trained Isha Kriya instructor.

For more on Sadhguru and Isha, visit IshaUSA.org/blog
results.name: Isha Kriya Guided Meditation--FREE Class (Online Webinar)

results.description:
Hi everyone! 

In a previous Bible Study, we talked about what it means to be a true Christian, by repenting of our sins, putting our faith in God through Christ and living lives worthy of our calling.  In Romans 8:13-14 Paul teaches us, "For if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die: but if you through the Spirit do mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live.   For as many as are led by the Spirit of God, they are the sons of God."


What then is the fate of everyone who does not repent, believe in Christ and live for God?  Will our unsaved loved ones spend an eternity in torment in hell?  Or does the Bible provide hope for those who have not understood the gospel in this life?

Get ready to read some verses that may surprise you.  1 Corinthians 15, Revelations 20, Ezekiel 37 and various other passages say some surprising things about God's plan of salvation that many of us may have never read or understood before.  In fact, God gave Israel 7 annual holy days that outline and celebrate highlights in His plan of salvation.  


Come join us for an inspiring and eye-opening discussion of a topic that demonstrates God's depth of compassion for mankind, and one that is rarely understood by modern Christians. 

I hope you can join us!
results.name: 1st & 3rd Saturday Bible Study:  "What Will Happen to the Unsaved?"

results.description:
This meet-up hosts family-friendly board game nights for those in East Cambridge and beyond. The fact that it's an inclusive group made up of singles as well as parents (with kids) makes it unique in the Greater Boston area.

Trinity Cambridge Church (www.trinitycambridge.com) sponsors our meet-up as a way to serve the Cambridge community. They provide free pizza for our meet-ups. We meet at the organizer's home, 217 Thorndike Street, Cambridge, which is a 10-minute walk from the Kendall and Lechmere T-stops. 

We gather every other week on Saturdays from 6-9pm. We specialize in Euro-style tabletop games of medium complexity. After grabbing some slices of pizza, we break into groups to play strategy games to entertain the adults (e.g. Dominion, Settlers of Catan, Avalon, Carcassone, Hanabi, Ticket to Ride, etc.) as well as simpler games to regale the kids (e.g. Dixit, Twirkle, Code Names, Skip-Bo, etc.). Usually, we have a volunteer or two to supervise the kids' games. If you have younger children who are not able to play the games, you will have to watch them yourself. 

Due to the limited space, you must RSVP and inform us of how many people are in your party. For this reason, we ask that you be considerate of others by RSVP'ing only if you are likely to attend. This also allows us to alert you in the event that the meet-up is cancelled.

We welcome beginners and advanced players, and you are invited to bring your own favorite games as well.
results.name: Let's meet up and play some board games!

If your plans change, please change your RSVP so that those on the waitlist can attend and so that I have an accurate count for planning purposes.

More game nights?

We can always use more game nights! So if you're interested in hosting one, please contact me and I'll be happy to help.

results.description:
Please note: I have picked the 615pm show.

In A BIGGER SPLASH, rock legend Marianne Lane (Tilda Swinton) is recuperating on the volcanic island of Pantelleria with her partner Paul (Matthias Schoenaerts) when iconoclast record producer and old flame Harry (Ralph Fiennes) unexpectedly arrives with his daughter Penelope (Dakota Johnson) and interrupts their holiday, bringing with him an A-bomb blast of nostalgia from which there can be no rescue. A BIGGER SPLASH is a sensuous portrait of desire, jealousy and rock and roll, under the Mediterranean sun. [from Rotten Tomatoes synopsis].

results.description:
MAXIMUM FOR THIS RESERVATION IS 22 PEOPLE. 

Mr. Dooley’s in WRENTHAM has the inviting atmosphere and quaint bar - it has quickly become the "local" of Wrentham.

From its imported lace curtains to the family pictures on the wall, it is a warm and inviting atmosphere that gives you a glimpse into the feel of John Joe's local in his hometown of Finuge, Listowel, county Kerry. Focusing on traditional Irish comfort food, we have an expansive menu ranging from our Guinness steak tips to fresh New England seafood. Mr. Dooley’s has gained a reputation in excellence for food and service.

Mr. Dooley's also has MUSIC from Wed. thru Saturday ranging from an open mic night to traditional Irish music, something for everyone to enjoy.

Mr. Dooley's is a place to come and lay your hat and have a pint and a chat, and plan on lots of laughing with this group!                   

DINNER MENU:  http://www.somerspubs.com/mr-dooleys/wrentham-menus/r-dinner.html
results.name: MR. DOOLEY'S

You're welcome to invite some friends as well. We look forward to seeing you there!

June 11th Dinner planning:  We'll also be planning the June 11th Dinner fund-raiser.  The dinner will be a buffet-style meal for $7.00 served from 4:30 - 6:30 pm and everyone is invited to attend.   Proceeds will be used for the meetup groups.  We'll have a volunteer list, and need cooks, servers, and clean up crew, and someone to sell the tickets at the door.
results.name: Game Night and Potluck Buffet!

results.description:
During a sweltering summer in New York City, 13-year-old Mister’s (Skylan Brooks) hard-living mother (Hudson) is apprehended by the police, leaving the boy and nine-year-old Pete (Dizon) alone to forage for food while dodging child protective services and the destructive scenarios of the Brooklyn projects. Faced with more than any child can be expected to bear, the resourceful Mister nevertheless feels he is an unstoppable force against seemingly unmovable obstacles. But what really keeps the pair in the survival game is much more Mister’s vulnerability than his larger-than-life attitude. Plus he and Pete have to figure out how to do all of this without money.

6:30pm - Doors open for reception. Includes music, food and drink.

7:30pm - Film screening


9:30pm - Post-film Discussion with Special Guests

results.description:
Note: This Meetup will always say "full" with only the organizer attending. In order to reserve your spot, you must sign up at www.llbean.com/mansfield

Please Join L.L.Bean Mansfield for our Sunset and Full Moon Hike up Great Blue Hill in the Blue Hills Reservation in Milton, MA. On this evening outing we will be hiking the Red Dot Trail to the Summit of Great Blue Hill. Once we summit we will look west and enjoy the spectacular sunset. After the sun slips below the horizon, we will hike to Eliot tower and watch the full moon (called The Full Flower Moon!) rise out of the Atlantic Ocean to the east and watch the Boston skyline come to life! We should cover about 3 miles and take approximately 2 hours. ACTIVITY LEVEL: Moderate. WHERE TO MEET: Large public parking lot located at 1904 Canton Ave. (Rt. 138), Milton, MA. This lot is just past the Blue Hills Ski Area and adjacent to the Blue Hills Trailside Museum. Look for Andy's Green Honda Pilot with the "L.L.Bean Outing Program“ banner on the side. If lost call Andy's cell[masked]-4503. WHAT TO BRING: Be prepared with weather-appropriate clothing (layers, no cotton), headlamp or flashlight , waterproof footwear, small day pack with extra clothes, snacks, lunch, water, personal medications. OPTIONAL RECOMMENDED ITEMS: Sunglasses, binoculars, camera, bug spray to protect from ticks and mosquitos.

Please sign up at www.llbean.com/mansfield
results.name: Sunset and Full Moon Hike to The Summit of Great Blue Hill !

results.description:
The next Cape Ann Contra Dance will be Saturday, May 21, at the Magnolia Library Community Center, 1 Lexington Avenue, Gloucester, MA. The dancing starts at 7:00 PM. No experience is necessary. All dances are taught. Dancers of all ages are welcome; attendees range from eight years to 80 plus years! Everyone has a great time listening and dancing to the live music provided by the Cape Ann Contra Band and Friends. There is a requested donation of $10 per dancer, dancers younger than 16 are free. Sit-in musicians are also welcome. We ask sit-ins to make a donation as well to help with the overhead.

For more information about sitting in, please visit: http://www.manystrings6.com/dance/dance5.html This event is supported in part by a grant from the Gloucester Cultural Council, a local agency which is supported by the Massachusetts Cultural Council, a state agency. The Cape Ann Contra Dances are organized and produced by Folk Life Studio. Drinking water is available. Please bring water bottles to reduce the use of paper cups. Other non-alcoholic drinks and finger food snacks are welcomed to share during the break. For more information,
contact [masked]
FInd us at: https://www.facebook.com/CapeAnnContraDance/

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE THAT AN RSVP HERE DOES NOT GUARANTEE YOUR SPOT. PLEASE MAKE PAYMENT TO [masked]  TO BE ADDED TO THE LIST.  THANK YOU!  <3  ROBYN

_________________________________

A Puja, in sanskrit, means reverence, honor, worship and adoration.  It's used by the Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, and others -- as a ceremony to honor a very special occasion; it's also used more often as part of a sacred ritual/practice to support opening to the wisdom of the Divine -- your Source.

_________________________________________

Here's what we are going to do:

_________________________________________

Intimate Puja Circles, created by Robyn Vogel, Come Back to Love Coach, is the place to:

• Be playful with other yummy, juicy, soulful singles, and couples

• Learn and practice Tantra, yoga, meditation, et al....

• Be in a room with folks who are willing to be honest, and open their hearts

• Experience deep connections with those interested in sacred sexuality, expanded orgasm, conscious relationship, spirituality  - people like YOU!

Tantric Intimacy (whether you are single or in relationship):

This special evening will begin with many invitations to connect with each other in light and playful ways -- always with the opportunity to go as deep as you choose.  Single or coupled, you'll experience Tantric Intimacy exercises as a way to say 'hello', get to know one another, mingle and connect. 

Here's what participants are saying!

"Thank you so much, Robyn!  I'm learning so much about myself through these Pujas and because of them would never have met my PARTNER!  Woo hoo!"

"The class was great; I  really enjoyed it. Very different from my normal way of life, you did create on a small scale what I was hoping for....creating the possibility to feel a deeper intimacy."

"It's so amazing to walk into a room of "strangers" and walk out feeling in love with everyone!"

"I didn't think I'd be able to connect with anyone there.  I was so surprised, and delighted, how easy it was to enjoy myself with every man in that room! Thank you Robyn, for your excellent facilitation skills. I felt totally safe!"

"We have to wait a whole month until the next one????"

"This is a very special event; a non-threatening, yet deep and authentic way to meet others. I've been online dating for years and it's just not for me.  I've met some really good people at your events."

"We love to come as a couple and meet others on a similar path."

"....and to think, they are happening RIGHT HERE in Boston!!


The Intimate Puja Circle itself will begin part-way through the night during which you'll have the chance to connect more deeply with others (one-on-one) -- this part of the evening will be facilitated, with a structure offered, however, you will have ample time to co-create with the beloved in front of you!!  You will be at choice and encouraged to ask for 100% of what you want.


Relax on a Friday night:

Once the formal part of the evening is over, there'll be time to dance, hang out, cuddle, snuggle, relax, process, and rest.  There will always be chocolate!


Q&A

1.  What if I'm in relationship? Being in relationship definitely does not exclude you from coming to the Intimate Puja Circle. These rituals will be invitations to connect with yourself and one another - and you will be at choice as to how you do that.  There are typically a mix of singles and couples at the events.

2.  What should I wear? Please be comfortable but also celebratory!  Wear yoga pants or something with a draw string around the waist; bring sarongs, scarves, dresses, etc.

3.  Do I need to bring anything? Yes, FRIENDS!!  And your water bottle.  You are also welcome healthy snacks to share after the Puja.  Organic fruit and chocolate are best.

4.  What if I have questions, I'm feeling a bit nervous: Please email me to set up a time to talk:  [masked]

Please note RSVPing on this Meetup site will not reserve you a space. The Intimate Puja Circles are limited in size so please pay in advance to reserve your space (and SAVE MONEY.)
results.name: Intimate Puja Circle (Everyone's Invited!)

results.description:
The Hand of God. I love my little hamsa pin. I love Kabbalah. I love doing healings involving the sacred sound of the Hamsa. The healing is a visualization of the Hamsa, the hand of God, touching your heart and strengthening the aura of protection around you. You're gonna feel it. Trust me!

This healing is all about resonating with protection and clarity in a world that can throw us a toxic curveball or two. The Hand (hamsa), particularly the open right hand, is a sign of protection that also represents blessings, power and strength, and is seen as potent in deflecting the evil eye. If you worry about losing your energy during the day or being affected by "negative' people, this healing is for you.

As for the healing itself, everyone will lie down on comfy mats in a beautiful temple (bring your own blanket) and enter into a state of deep relaxation as I play my tibetan bowls and gongs and drum. As I go to do healing work with each one of you, everyone else benefits from the shifts that occur in more ways than one. I hope you can join me on the 21st ... If you want me to personalize your healing, beforehand call me at[masked]-8601. I make no claims for what I do. I merely facilitate and hold space for the healing and transformation you need to do yourself. Please arrive promptly out of respect to others attending the healing!

An energetic contribution for this event keeps the cycle flowing!

Thanks and love,

Brian
results.name: Hand of God Healing

results.description:
Let's dance salsa!

Saturday Night Salsa is Boston's biggest salsa dance party on Saturday featuring salsa dancing and lessons with Salsa y Control, an amazing venue filled with 300+ welcoming salsa dancers, an inexpensive parking garage next door, and public transport on Mass Ave. (Red Line, Buses 1, 64 etc.) one block away!

9:00-10:00 pm:  Beginner & Intermediate. Salsa Lessons
10:00-2 am: Dance Party * No Partner Required

Lets meet at 9 pm (facing the stage) at the right side of the stage.

There are some tables alongside the wall. These tables are typically first come, first serve, so if we all arrive at the same time and early, we can occupy these tables.

I will try  to post a Meetup sign at one of these tables.  These tables can serve as our meeting point through out the night.  Last time I asked for permission and  management informed me that posting signs was not allowed. However, if you are on time, you will definitely connect with the group.  

Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.  This is an actual event, not an advertisement. 


Please be on time! If you arrive late, I can not guarantee that you will be able to recognize members of the group from the crowds. 

This should be a super fun event and a super friendly event for salsa beginners and the advanced dancers.  


A tip, if you are a beginner, you definitely want to come early and participate in the lesson and connect with other beginners.  The first half of this event is the most beginner friendly part of the night.  Advanced dancers usually come later  in the night after the lessons are done.  Some beginners may feel intimated arriving so late in the night.  

I am really looking forward to enjoying this event as part of the group.

Wear comfortable shoes!

Joana

******************************************************************************************************************************

Event Details

Beginners Very Welcome

No partner required

$12 - Admission includes lesson and party

Dress Code: Smart Casual to Elegant (No ball caps, no work boots, etc.)

Beer, Wine, Mixed Drinks, etc. available at Bar

Music format: 65% salsa, 25% bachata, 10% merengue/cha cha

***********************************
Driving Directions: Take Storrow or Memorial Drive to River St. (where the two gas stations are), then a right on Mass Ave, a right on Pearl St (where FootLocker and Putnam Furniture is), and your first right on Green St.

Parking: There is a large, inexpensive ($1.50/hr)parking garage right next door - you can't miss it!

Walking Directions (from Red Line's Central Stop): From Mass Ave take a left on Prospect St then a left on Green St. It is a one minute walk.

Please note that the Night Salsa parties are 21+.

* Don't forget your ID!

http://www.havanaclubsalsa.com
results.how_to_find_us: Right side of the stage at 9 pm sharp!
results.name: Lets Dance Salsa!  at the Havana Club in Central Square! Lesson Included!

results.description:
Once you register on Southborough Recreation Sports Meetup you can RSVP to play in all the Meetups you want. The $15 per month fee will be collected when you show up to play and will cover you for that month.

Doubles, Mixed Doubles, Singles matches will be played on outdoor hard-courts. All levels 3.0 and higher welcome. You must be able to serve over-head, volley and rally. New tennis balls for each court will be provided.

Based on play level you indicated in your profile initially you will be matched up with similar level players. Adjustment to level may be done based on actual play. Players participating in a session will be emailed the day before with court assignment. You decide on starting teams on each court.

All guests must also register, RSVP and pay the fee to participate. This will ensure we have a spot for your guest...matched to players of similar skill-level.

1st Session matches are from 8:00-8:50AM and 8:50-9:30AM. 2nd Session matches are from 9:30-10:15AM and 10:15-11:00AM. You must RSVP to both sessions if you wish to play from 8AM to 11AM. Matches are w/Ad scoring. Leading team moves up & splits. Other team moves down & splits.

Occasionally, we will have to play at other locations on days ARHS has events. Organizer will change location on the meetup description.

Rain and/or wet courts may force cancellation which will be communicated via e-mail as early as possible.

All players play at their own risk at all times.

Organizers reserve the right to remove any player from the RSVP list or this social tennis Group or the courts at any time for any reason without advance notice.

Sunday, May 22, 2016, at DCR Baxter Park at Assembly Row in Somerville, marks the exciting debut of a new family-friendly spring fundraiser, the Fast and Furriest 5K – Run, Walk, Wag! This new community event, which will combine the interests of past Walk for Animals and Run Fur Fun participants, will include a timed 5K fun run, a shorter walk, and a “Ducky Dash” kids’ fun run – each including canines, of course.  The run and walk will be followed by activities, vendor booths, food, contests, and entertainment for the whole family. The cost to participate is $30 for adults and $10 for children, with the opportunity to fundraise and win amazing prizes! All funds raised will benefit all the animals served in our adoption centers, hospitals, and programs.

results.description:
On Sunday May 22, ride to raise money and awareness for diabetes. The ride starts at the Topsfield Fairgrounds and is run by the American Diabetes Association. There are 4 routes - 15 miles, 31 miles, 62 miles, or 100 miles, and they are arrowed. To participate you must sign up AT THE ADA website - you can get more information or register here: http://www.diabetes.org/northshoretour

RSVP'ing here to the Meetup isn't enough.

On the day of the Tour de Cure, all riders get free lunch, snacks at rest stops, and a T-shirt. There is a fundraising minimum of only $250 plus a $25 registration fee. The website gives you a Participant Center web page which helps you send out emails to people asking for them to sponsor you. At various levels of fundraising (starting at $500) you can get a reward from a list of choices - the more you raise, the better the choices.

When you register, you join a team. There are corporate teams and friends/family teams and there's a general team (Team Red) which I rode with my first year. If you like, you can join my team - I'm the captain of Team Oracle New England - you don't have to work at Oracle to join.

I hope some of you will do this ride, it's really a lot of fun and very well organized.
results.name: Ride in the North Shore Tour de Cure to stop diabetes!

results.description: I am super excited about this! Let's have our first of many "Be Fast" meet ups this Sunday May 22. I will meet with anyone who wants to go for a run and then enjoy breakfast at In House Cafe in Brighton! I live in Allston, if any of you are familiar with the area or taken the B trolley on the Green line, we can meet at the Blanford Street stop(the 1st street level stop) & we are steps from the Charles River. Enjoy a beautiful site, get our sweat on, take pictures then my favorite, eat! The cafe I go to is really yummy, reasonable prices (I would bring $20, which is more than enough) They do reserve tables so I would like to give them a heads up by this Friday on how many will come! I look forward to meeting all of you! Let's go!

results.description:
The Sun in your Pocket

A workshop on mastering  Flash - Nikon and Canon and other makes are all welcome

If you’re at all curious about flash and want to have a complete introduction to how to use it in your photography then this one day intensive is for you.

Don’t have a Speedlight of your own – no problem,  there are a handful available for you to try out during the class.

Specifically tailored for Canon and Nikon Speedlight users this class may cover:

•The best uses for on- and off-camera Speedlights

•Deciding between Manual and E-TTL flash control

•Putting Flash Exposure Compensation to use

•Grip gear for Speedlites - from ultra-portable to ultra-sturdy

•On-flash modifiers: grids, snoots, diffusers, ringlight adapters, etc.

•Off-flash modifiers: umbrellas, softboxes, diffusion panels, reflectors, beauty dish, etc.

•Using your Speedlights bounce and zoom as a light modifier

•Corded solutions for moving your Speedlite off-camera

•Sorting out radio triggers: dumb vs. intelligent

•Setting up the flash  as a wireless Master

•Setting up the flash as a wireless Slave

•Organizing multiple Speedlites with Groups and Channels

•All the Syncs: High-speed, 1st-curtain, 2nd-curtain, Slow-speed

•Custom functions: optimizing your Speedlites

•Strategies for portrait lighting

•Strategies for product / food lighting

•Strategies for event / wedding photography

•Fill-flash techniques

•Using gels for color correction and dramatic effects

•Battery charging and storage

•One-, two-, three-Speedlight kits (and beyond!)

•Gang light: the how and why of firing a large number of Speedlights together

•Using Speedlights with studio lights

Suitable for all levels, you will receive expert instruction on how to get the best from your Speedlight in a host of situations.

At the end of the workshop you will feel confident setting your Speedlight’s controls to get the best shot you can get. You will know the advantages and disadvantages of TTL versus Manual operation and will have experienced the many ways in which your speedlight can be modified.
results.how_to_find_us: Enter through the EMTS door and head for the second floor
results.name: The Sun in Your Pocket - Introduction to Flash

results.description:
The Sanctuary Meditation 

An experiential class teaching you how to easily and safely expand your consciousness to reach the realm of your own personal spiritual sanctuary, meet with your Higher Self and receive clear guidance from your inner wisdom. 

A fascinating meditation process handed down by the Mystery School tradition (on the Hermetic Ray) for thousands of years. 

In this class you will follow a series of steps that will • open and expand the chakras

• evoke the 3 Sacred Geometries of Creation to create an astral vehicle

• safely and easily ascend through the dimensions of reality

• meet your higher self to attain Self knowledge 

This method is a foundational practice that can be used daily or as often as needed. 

You can use this as a tool to steer your own ship and become a master of your own destiny, building upon a foundation for all and any spiritual practice.


Please RSVP by Saturday the 21st so I can prep materials for each guest, and honor your commitment (show up if you say you are coming) 

$40 cash at door / 2.5 hours

No meditation experience required!
